author: chrissorem
content: Shawn likes to paint himself into corners that most people would jump ship. I’ve seen him work himself out of them and come up with the great and unusual results. He’s extremely clever and has a natural punk rock approach to things. I’ve watched him mix numerous times and left thinking I could never make anything sound good in that room or with that approach but he’s managed to figure it out. It’s not always fast or easy but it’s always unique whether you like it or not. He’s been a huge inspiration to me and a constant reminder that we are making art not products.  I’d like to see more engineers following their own instincts and spending less time looking at what everyone else is doing.

author: bobby k
content: shifting gears for a sec - something i've been a big fan of this year is duplicating a lead vocal and stripping back any compression / dynamic control to a secondary track with no output, then putting any reverb sends on that track instead of the main ldv. this saves pretty much any instinctual reverb automation "throws" and the such because the vocals natural dynamic is lighting up the reverb the same way it would in real life. it now strikes me how odd and unnatural it would sound to have a vocal hitting the reverb about as hard during soft moments as during dynamic moments. unfortunately there are many cases where this is simply not possible as i'm already starting with a heavily compressed vocal. maybe i'm late to this, but anybody else do this or something similar with success?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Yep Rob just mixed Church. It was already taking off so they let it be as it was, then had Schepps do the rest.


I started out as an intern with Rob for a year in Dublin just after the Hozier album, and I remember him saying how when he got the mixes back, for a moment he thought he’d been sent the wrong files - the mixes felt the same, they just sounded better.

I learned so much from him and his approach to record making. Was actually thinking about how well he paces sessions when the convo about keeping artists “under control” came up.

He’s an amazing story teller, and has an infinite well of classics from his time with U2, Eno and Flood. He would alternate between having everyone in the room totally focused on getting their take or the part or whatever, then lift that pressure completely off with a hilarious story. Everyone would get to take a mental break, then after that pause they’d be ready to go full bore again. I’ve never seen albums come together as smoothly and painlessly as the ones I’ve worked on with him.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Doing tracks for live-show is a different beast than making a record. 

The impact and immersion of a record vs the live show are also different beasts. The art of the live show must include the spirit of the record, knowing that’s what the audience knows, but also must elevate it or mutate in a way to make that live show tantamount, at least for the people in the room that night. The “Yeah but have you seen them live?” question is the goal of every artist (and music director) but that’s always gonna be an exclusive subset of fans with real buy-in. 

As a producer, and an MD, (who’s also been an artist,) I firmly believe the studio and the stage are unique mediums, and that each should inform, without ever hindering, the other.

author: bobby k
content: a trick i’ve loved in ableton is putting the vocoder before the drum verb and just leaving it on white noise mode. it strips all the tonality out and just mocks up the transients n stuff as white noise, then sending that to a reverb and blending it in with the drum group. creates a nice sizzle on top of stuff but also digs deep enough to feel like a verb reacting to low end from the kick. worth a shot.

I love the phenomena where having someone sit in the room while you’re working on a mix forces you out of your own head and into the perspective of the listener. It really ought to be common practice.

There should be a buddy-system for mixers where we visit each other’s studios and sit down quietly for a playback and then leave without saying a word.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’d like to unpack this for a bit, cause this resonates, and I’ve had long conversations with my mentors about it. 

Also, as someone who’s heard a fair bit of your work, I can say with my whole mouth that your output is EXCELLENT. 

1) a lot of the records we love were painstakingly put together by teams of people over long periods of time. We’re banging out productions all by ourselves in a small room at breakneck speeds. 

2) when you’re responsible for the writing, recording AND performing, and *then* the mixing, there’s no possible way to achieve the perspective required to ever feel like it’s a masterpiece.  

3) and perhaps most important: our ears are always going to be better than our craft. We’ve been listening to music for so long, and even as we continue to learn the craft our ears continue to grow as well. I think that’s part of the thing that makes making music so beautifully elusive, so satisfying and unsatisfying. It’s the thing that keeps us chasing. 

4) always looking for the next thing to help unlock the next thing is a great mindset AS LONG AS we remember there’s no silver bullet. Never was and never will be. 

I’ll get off my soap box now.

Putting a super wet reverb on the master puts this Gaussian blur across the whole thing and usually the leveling of things ironically becomes clearer.  Take it off when you’re ready Ofcourse ha.

author: cian riordan
content: This song showed up on Eric Valentine's desk almost a decade ago when I was engineering for him. We were in this sweet spot after I graduated out of assisting him and before we got sick of being a room together... so I got to be a lot more hands on. The files came in *roooughhh*. Eric's response was simply "it has to sound great, they're paying us a ton of money"... so everyone in the studio divided and conquered... I replayed the bass and some drum stuff, Eric replayed a lot of the guitars, we both added to the background vocals. The parts were all bone headed but it made such a huge difference sonically to be working with real sounds as opposed to the demo recordings that got greenlit by the label. author: Adam Thein
content: Pretty sure I stole this trick somewhere from someone but repeating here cause it's been saving me time getting reverbs slotted but basically put spectre in 100% wet and move a band around after a reverb to find a good little slot for the vocal EQ while also controlling the dynamics a bit with the saturation and then you can flip through the styles to find a good texture that works in that range. author: Slow Hand
content:
A recent lesson that I've had to remind myself about was the importance of narrowing my long reverbs. Recently I've had a bad habit of keeping them full-width.

I've found that it really helps my soundstage if I don't let the long verbs touch the far-left or far-right of my mix. The more I narrow my verbs the deeper it feels like my sound stage will go. Like a vanishing point on the horizon. It also opens up a lot more sonic real-estate because now elements that are panned don't have to compete with a wide reverb wash.

Keeping those big verbs away from the extreme edges of my soundstage also creates contrast against my hard-panned elements and make them feel more forward.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
when it comes to frequency response of a monitoring setup, i think people way over estimate the contribution of the speaker and way under estimate the contribution of the room.

i just spent two days working on the monitoring in my new spot. one day with @cian riordan and one day with the unfuck guys. the room was built by some professional person with a floated floor and cloud and non parallel walls etc etc, and the imperfections are ALL in the room.

not saying people shouldn't have preferences between PMC, ATC, etc. But with the exception of the 6 figure mastering level rooms i've been in, the room is always the limiting factor in my experience.

author: sethearnest
content:
The main stereo verb swimming the whole time has a lot of pre-delay on it and it doesn’t have any of the high freq info in it. A dark, pre-delayed verb will tuck behind a vocal well and allow the verb to be noticed but not push back the vocal b/c the vocal itself is bright and “dry” for 50ms or 80ms or however long the pre-delay is, both of which keep things “close” to our ears. There also doesn’t seem to be any center of that verb—it’s all wide, so that helps keep the vocal clear. There’s a mono dark delay throw happening here and there, too, which gives some good front to back depth. 

Also sounds like some compression or ducking (or however they did it) on the verb that opens up between the lyric spaces, so yet another thing that helps keep the vocal dry-but-also-wet feeling.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Lotsa great thoughts here from everyone, of course. I have a feeling you know all this tho- and what you actually need is perspective… either time away or listening with someone else in the room to reveal where the issues are, and the solutions that come with. 

If you don’t have time or people you trust to help get that perspective, try muting shit in the verses or interludes or choruses or posts, see what you can & can’t live without. If every part matters, than saving the very top & bottom for the choruses is a good move. 
I was always focused on stereo field, but going taller on the choruses is also on my Must list. 

And finally, detailing moments is truly where my heart is- so I love figuring out how to make every element that leads to the downbeat create the feeling of pregnant inevitably. Sometimes a super modded verb throw or a reverse that mutes right before the downbeat… somehow making things fall apart like a nude descending the staircase, then snap back together for the next downbeat… 
Assuming you’re mixing your own productions, the world’s your oyster. But even if your not, go Fucken nuts and see what the client says. IME, 9/10 they’re looking for your creativity too…. 
Tl;dr, you got this, you just need a nap.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I picked up Jon and @oaklandmatt ‘s tip and started doing throws pretty exclusively directly on tracks. 

When the lead vocal is most of the way there (maybe there’ll be subtle adjustments to the LV processing, but it’s more or less up to EU regulations), I do a *commit up to this insert* (which keeps it mono, rather than a right click commit on the track title) on the whole vocal. 

I mute the entire resulting clip, then just unmute the bits I need for a given throw. I’ll duplicate this track (without inserts), maybe end up with 4 of them with different FX chains. It’s no biggie just for a H-Delay and a vintageverb/metaflanger/ whatever.

Like they mentioned on the podcast, this method encourages more experimentation for me, and also circumvents niggly things like trying to get a word to echo on the downbeat if it was sung on an offbeat - you just move the clip forward or backward in time. And if an Ess is too apparent, you can clip gain it down in the source etc.

Plus once you have your verb throw set, when you in turn commit that throw, whatever it is about seeing the audio just suggests further details like having it cut abruptly on a beat, or reverse it, or fade it in, or EQ it etc.

author: ALXCPH
content:
theres so many ways to interpret this question. so here's my take. Mixing to me at least, is all about bringing out the intent of the record to the best of your abilities. Fx. if you are mixing a Classical record, all you aim for is probably getting something as close to being in the room as possible, and therefore fidelity. If you are mixing some new urban underground cultural music, you want to respect the grittiness as that can sometimes be part of the sound and/or culture, and you never want to remove the inherent DNA of what makes that thing exciting(even tho it might be unconventional). So in the end, it's OUR job to make the decisions on when to be rough and when to be high fidelity. It's all about what you want out of the music. For most mainstream music(aka. radio oriented) i would personally get a bit of both. Get the mix sounding somewhat exciting as to pull in the listener, but also have certain aspects be high fidelity as to make it easy to listen to. FX, in a pop record, Vocal intelligibility is super important if you want people to sing along, where are in a techno track or hyperpop track you can have some grittier vocals, as they aren't as intended to be the in the car sing along song. They would be much more about the energy and feeling. 

IMO theres nothing more boring than a perfect mix, where every sound is perfectly inline and has no personality that makes it memorable. 

The creativity of a mix is just as, if not more important, than the technicals. Thats what those cyborgs called Mastering Engineers are for.

author: sethmanchester
content: I used to do consistent audiobook work 15+ years ago to supplement studio work. It was brutal work and I hated it. RX didn’t exist yet, or was in it’s infancy and sounded terrible. I’d record and edit, used an m930 because of the low self noise which was huge for me around the time. My editing trick was to make a 5 min room tone loop the length of the book, duplicate the dialog, strip silence one track, using the dup track as a trigger to extract silence for the other track with the room tone selected, delete the dup track. In object mode select all the audio then it’s something like shift + drag to fill the gaps from strip silence with the extracted room tone. Always used beat detective to do batch cross fades. Then listen through and correct to taste. RX declick would have been a game changer back then but I did all that shit by hand, if there was a pop on a word you’d aim to find a similar syllable somewhere else to replace it with. At the time I was getting paid $250/finished hour for editing and $300 for tracking which was really good considering I could edit around 1.5:1 but tracking was always closer to 3:1. Budgets started shrinking right around the advent of RX. When I started, there was always an engineer, producer and proofer in the room for tracking. All lunches paid for. After enough experience I was able to provide all three which made it pretty lucrative. But the industry changed and eventually it was just engineer and reader which put a lot of pressure on the engineer to produce and proof. The  publisher I worked with stopped paying for lunch then dropped my fee to $250/$200 then $225/$175 then $200/$150 and once it hit $175/$125 I saw the writing on the wall and vowed never to do it again. I will say it upped my Pro Tools keyboard speed tremendously and kept my studio afloat early on. The halycon days of audiobook production are long gone as far as finaces are concerned.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As Justin and Zack said, there's no wrong answer here. It's achievable both ways.

But since you're having trouble getting your verbs to pop out in the way you want, here are a few things that will get you there. Usually a combination of these things:

**1.** Turn up the verb - Simple, I know.
**2.** Make space for the verb - Mute or EQ competing elements.
**3.** Increase your pre-delay time to the range of 60ms - 150 ms. This "disconnects" your verb from the source and makes it stand out more. And this sometimes means you can turn it down and still have the clarity. 
**4.** Use an echo instead of a verb - This sometimes does the thing and takes up less space.
**5.** Use a slap echo instead of a verb - One and done. Gives you that room-y feel without taking up a lot of space.
**6.** EQ muddy/thick/harsh frequencies out of your verb, so that you can turn it up louder without overwhelming the mix.
**7.** Gently apply an effect (distortion, phaser, etc) that will make it contrast and catch the ear easier.

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The one piece of advice I’d give. Restrict his tools. One EQ, one good compressor, one good delay, a couple of verbs

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. Soft synth patches are often programmed to take up a massive amount of space and sound as impressive as possible. It's a pet-peeve of mine when presets are dripping in verb and echo. I wish more synths had a master-echo bypass option across all patches.

I also immediately turn off any stereo-widening or spatial effects, and/or reduce it to mono by dropping a channel or narrowing it with a utility plugin.

Funnily it took me a while to internalize the lesson that most mix elements sound best closer to mono.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I also think mono reverbs help a lot, esp. once you get several of them fed from different instruments and panned all over to create a stereo ambience. Often more immersive (and less muddy) than multiple instruments all going to the same stereo verb or two.

content: Indeed. Learning to hear masking is a never ending journey. You have to be able to step back and hear it as a master and think does this mix have to much 3k? Then jump back into mixing mode and look for relief. This is the reason solo mixing doesn’t work. Often times I’ll be doing mix notes with someone in the room and they will say something on the lines of the drums feel bright and I’ll take a dip out of the guitars and all of the sudden the drums are fine.  This is also the he reason I try and steer the notes sessions to what is not happening in the mix that you’d like to feel, rather than can I hear the drums soled ect

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Just come back to a mix after 4 days away from it. author: BatMeckley
content:
Little Marshall MS-2, which id brought to the session because I’d just read that’s what they used on the bass for Song 2 by blur.  It was a great lesson in how to actually make records, because while I was sitting in the control room figuring out how to mic the thing as an effect, how to patch it in, etc, Jon just had grabbed the thing, plugged in a mic with a 1/4” jack and was holding it up in their vocal booth, and I was like “well shit, I guess that works”. 

Also, we had a 2 bar clapping sample off a popular radio song, and he just held up his iPhone to the mic to sample it. We (I) can really over think things sometimes.

They had the entirety of the song written and pretty much 90% of it recorded by 6pm dinner.

author: cian riordan
content: All super fair. Your next step is to get out and network. I'm not sure what genres you're working in... but you need to find inroads to other people in similar circles. This can begin online, but it requires getting in the room with folks -- whether its production/writing sessions, going to shows, just grabbing drinks with peers. You can be the best mixer on the planet, but if nobody knows who you are or has a sense of what you're capable of -- it's moot.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Anyone here ever use transient designers before their reverbs to soften the attack? 

Maybe I'm late to the party here, but doing so can make a grainy-sounding algo reverb a whole lot smoother if you dull the transient. I'm looking forward to exploring this more.

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW: I never use auto align and have only used time adjuster to move room mics a little further away for effect. If things aren’t sounding locked with a simple polarity flip, I’ll quickly try and tinker with a HPF on key drum elements (kick, snare, etc). After that, I’ll resort to mountain moving EQ or samples. If someone didn’t have the skills and/or thought to record their drum mics in phase, then it’s very likely they’re not worth going through brain surgery to salvage them. Get them doing the fundamentals and move on with the mix.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Using a delay plugin for your pre-delays is nice for a couple of reasons:
A) Tempo-synced pre-delay values
B) You can do things like ping-pong or spread the imaging of your pre-delays for additional effect
C) If the delay has tone-shaping features with different personalities (like on Echo Boy Jr.) you can quickly apply different sonic character to the signal going into your reverb.

author: peterlabberton
content: For another data point, I assisted Joe Chiccarelli mixing a Hellogoodbye album. He did two songs each day over a week long session. They were all prepped ahead of time, and he was mixing on the console. So he could pull up a session, assign the outputs to the console channels, and go. Once the first song was done, there was a good template routed in the studio for all the rest and he burned through them quickly. Also the client was in the room, so any revisions were done in the room in real time—walked out of the studio at the end of the week with a finished and approved album.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Nope.  Bad arrangement.
This is why I harp on bedroom guitarists vs recording vs touring guitarist. If you’re by yourself a big meaty full frequency tone is satisfying. If you’re tracking guitars youre high passing so much more than you’d initially think to make room for bass and kick. If you’re in your bedroom, a tube screamer kinda blows. If you’re in a raging band and need a solo to tighten up and cut through the mix, a tube screamer is the way to go. That key guitar hook? More often than not is tracked through something like a pignose. Way band limited.

author: Slow Hand
content:
This reminds me of an important point: Most sounds in the mix don't actually need to be stereo. And a snare drum is probably not one of them. You can create a lot of space in your mix by reducing all but a few key elements to mono. Keyboards and synths are a huge offender here.

A lot of mixers/producers assume that the instruments need to be stereo, when in fact it's the *mix* that should be stereo. And the most "stereo" mix is often created by panning mono instruments in the stereo field. Getting those pan balances right is going to remove a lot of conflict between instruments sharing similar frequency ranges.

You can still have stereo reverbs and echoes, but they can often be far more narrow than the default setting of 100% width. So don't overlook narrowing your stereo elements too.

It's amazing how much you can do with nothing but faders, pan knobs, and EQ.

This goes counter to a lot of the conventional wisdom here, but I’ve always found listening somewhere else, while doing something else, incredibly helpful. When mixing, I try to take  some time to take in music the way that most people do, which isn’t hunched in front of my expensive monitors in my treated room hyper analyzing the 4k. 

Yesterday I was asking my buddy Spencer who lives in Georgia about a drum edit, and I could hear him listening to the song through the phone and realized the vocals were too hot. 

Little things like that can help me recenter on what’s important.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
If the reverb's there from production and has to stay:

- It doesn't always need to be heard, sometimes can just be felt
- Sometimes it can be drastically EQd
- Sometimes automated so it's clearly audible when there's space for it, and tucked when there isn't
- Sometimes complementary (but different!) mono ambiences panned around maintain more breathing room than a stereo ambience that might blur the center. Tchad Blake is very good at this sort of thing.

If the reverb's coming from me, added in the mix, and it's not working quickly, I'll take a second and consider whether I've been barking up the wrong tree

author: Deleted User
content: At a certain price point(up to 2-3k€) I probably would reach for a dynamic mic or ribbon, speaking very generally. A dynamic can be cool to minimize room engagement, which can be great if the singer is loud and the room isn’t great. David Bock’s paper on capsules is really enlightening. I would definitely try and avoid a chinese capsule a la Rode mics, but the mic amp is also very important. I’d avoid condensers that have intense artifacts at high SPL because of their mic amp circuits(Brauner Phantom and the Neumann TLM series come to mind). It can be quite hard to find a condenser that has that vintage-U47 style body under a certain level of investment, which is why I might reach for a large-diaphragm dynamic or a ribbon(and boost highs). I’d what that low-mid body to balance out the density in the high mids. But I’m mostly talking about belly tenors here, with Betty female singer I would probably be fine with something with less body(like a U67-style mic) It’s quite an in-depth topic I find, you can hit me in the dms if you have specific questions.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
So for this song I was hired to produce and mix it. I got the stems from the demo and did the production in ableton. Then vocals were recut in London and I was sent a Pro Tools session. I always cut and edit in Pro Tools, so I used this session to comp and arrange the new vocals, but then I wanted to just bring it back into ableton and blend with the existing production. So I bounced the vocal from Pro Tools dry  (no verb or delay) but with tuning and some compression and EQ. Then I used some of the demo vocal and some of the new vocal in the final mix.

I'm pretty comfortable committing eq and compression on my vocals (the confidence of years of doing this... ps you should do it more, it's good for the workflow). But if I needed to go back for some reason I could go back to the Pro Tools session. I think I did go back once to remove tuning on an ad lib that was part singing, part talking. 

I'm getting much more comfortable mixing in ableton. The only thing that really sucks about it is that the sessions do tend to slow down when there's TONS of vocals with autotune inserts (the equivalent number of tracks and autotune instances in pro tools does not tax Pro Tools nearly in the same way). So thus far the only way that ableton really works for me to both produce and mix in is if I don't have raw vocals in there. Hence, bouncing from pro tools works best anyway.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm finally getting around to listening to this excellent interview and Sean mentions that before synthetic reverbs were a thing, one technique that people sometimes used to get massive-sounding reverbs on record was to:

A) Make scale models of a concert hall 
B) Pump the scale model full of argon (which doesn't absorb high frequencies like our atmosphere does) 
C) Re-amp the instrument or record into the argon-filled scale model and then 
D) play the re-amped sound at a slower speed in order to get a long tail for a massive hall sound 😮.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Surprise surprise ima jump in with some Brauer bullshit again- zooming out of the vocal for a second, cuz I think the choices you’re talking about making, when made in a vacuum, can lead you to very different places depending on what you’re already hearing when you start adding vox fx. 

The idea is to identify the 2 or 3 things that the brain can actually focus on at any given moment in a song as the leading roles. Song I was on the other day had horns, vocal, and occasionally gtr were leading and everything else was just supporting (either octaves of the same part, rhythmically the same, or pads on keys). So I got those 3 rocking together without worrying about every track, it was easy to identify the kind of space I needed. I wanted it in the same room as the brass, but really forward on the stage. If I’d had the pads up while trying to do this I was always either too wet or too dry and couldn’t find the happy place. The tl;dr is, if you’re struggling to find a satisfying construction of ideas, you may be trying to treat leading and supporting parts as equally important, and you’re challenging your ear to grab what’s really important at that moment. 

Also in Brauer’s template there are a folder of verbs that everything in the session shares including vocals. So you get a sense of cohesion from that, and the vocals have their own folder of delays that are unique to them. That helps create separation.

author: JustinLeu
content:
A few more thoughts/ideas that I really like to do.

If using verb as an insert on an instrument:
- on insert 1–put Mondomod (or any panning plugin that will change the track from mono to stereo)  then use this as the pan before the reverb. This lets you place the instrument in the stereo field of the reverb. Doing it with mondo mod allows you to keep it static but also automate movement (small or large) within the verb 🙂

Another idea:
Use Waves StudioVerse (or similar plugin that allows this routing)
-parallel split the dry/wet 
-wet gets what ever verb you want
-Leave the wet panned out-wide
-pan the dry in towards the middle 

Doing it with StudioVerse allows you to avoid making aux-sends and keep it all on the track level. (Very useful on bgvs)

Last idea:
Use a pan control plugin (S1, TrackControl, etc) after the verb so you can make it more mono if you want. 

I love verb/dly haha thanks for letting me talk  about it here…my wife is tired of hearing about it 🥲

author: bryan cook
content:
check out an ever so slightly delayed distortion so you get that diction *and* the hair, just later hair. i like memory man to sansamp. the dark memory man fuzzes up well. I like to push the “punch” lower mid eq before the sansamp gain stage and then roll off bass and treble on the sansamp as well. sometimes lpf and hpf the memory man / sansamp after the fact. making this dirty slap midrangey really helps it not compete with the real or good sounding vocal and fulfill a different role.

delayed distortion can kind of be like predelayed verbs. keeping it forward and getting the vibe stuff. best of both worlds.

author: Deleted User
content: I like to think of it as these three terms. 1) EQ/Sauce - no predelay or barely any (sometimes I compress it to play with the shape of it too) 2) space - 50 to 80ms (or use mix of reverb with no predelay on a slap with slightly longer delay time) 3) bloom 90-200ms. I usually just put a time delay on it before reverb if I want musically timed reverb, but I personally tend not to go towards that direction very often. I’m also a big throws person so mostly my main reverb that are sent to aux tracks have medium to longer predelay and throws would have shorter predelay. Sometimes it’s the other way around too. I also like to make decisions based on how long I want the vocals to be closeup for before I hear the reverb kick in. Or I also print reverb sometimes and nudge it around in different parts and play with fades if I wanna get really sculpt-y with it. I do this with reverb throws (dups clips to audio tracks rather than sends) more often than send verbs.

author: ehutton21
content:
Late to the party but just wanted to add that I think time away from the mix can really help this process too. It’s not sexy but it’s ol’ reliable. 

In lieu of that though, I’ll try to bring something original to the party but it’s more arrangement based than sheer mix advice (but everything starts in the arrangement!)

Resolution of tension is what makes pop choruses satisfying, both harmonically and dynamically. In theory, this emphasizes what @Zack Hames and others said—good choruses shines because of contrast. Often times, if you have a build up to a chorus or a transition into it, I like to look at the “easy to undercook” elements like risers/rev reverbs, beat cuts, and harmonic layers/white noise to ensure there’s that layer of “ooo,” “aaa,” and “wow”. Good rev verbs/risers shouldn’t just be random white noise, I find a lot of success in tuning them and then automating the tuning so the pitch rises as well. Play with that. A great beat cut on the last count before a chorus is a killer idea. Try cutting the melodic elements and leaving the bass, maybe cutting everything—listen to some Neptunes era stuff for inspo, or just more Neptunes in general honestly for pop music references.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well if it's a sequenced track where I can be very pliable with the tempo one thing I'll do is to slowly adjust the tempo up and down and listen to the spaces *in between* the notes. I'll observe how that affects the feel.

Going slower will open up some space between the notes and give them a little more sense of  weight. Sometimes going too fast will make things feel cramped, or it may give it some urgency. If the song is groove-oriented this has a massive effect on the feel. Go figure.

Get up and dance. Observe your body and ask yourself how it feels. Does your body want to go quicker? Or does it feel better if it's laid back a bit? Imagine if the context that the song will be heard in. Is it a chill scenario? Or is it banging in a club where it might want some more push.

Sometimes the best tempo for a performance changes based on the acoustics of the room. Things like the pre-delay or tail are going to rhythmically inform you. And sometimes we key into the pulse that we feel from the echo in the room and conform to that implied rhythm.

It's kind of like how horn players will naturally discover the best sounding spot in the room for them if you allow them to wander around and play. Listen to the space and what it's telling you.

If I'm working with a live band I'll have them play to a click at a couple different speeds and ask them how it makes them feel. I'll have my own thoughts too, but getting the band thinking about it opens up fun conversations. Maybe they'll discover that Section A feels good at one tempo and then Section B is better if they speed it up a hair.

author: stefanmacc
content: This might be way overboard for your problem haha . But I had this issue on a mix that was sent to me… and what ended up working for me was to basically Re-amp the close mics one at a time into my live room through a speaker. And then lay a snare or kick drum against / on top of said speaker … and re record the decay of the new drum. It sometimes helped to roll off all the high and boost the low end of the shit re amp sound to get the drum to vibrate or move more air … and I was basically able to get real drums played exactly like the original but with the specific tone / decay I wanted. Then I would just blend these new recordings to taste …

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Mixing / Production: where do you draw the line?

I've been mixing an album where a lot of the parts have required chonky lifting to get them where they need to be - drums replaced, guitars replayed, creative reamping - manipulation that adds up to wholesale creating identities for parts, which in some cases adds up to manufacturing an identity for the production in post. In some cases, vibe and groove now exist where they did not in the roughs.

@cian riordan I was listening back to your Conversations episode recently, re the greatest fear being "what's turning up on my desk today?" and hoping it won't be up to you to manufacture the required ingredients. I find myself manufacturing a lot of ingredients 🥲

The artist and team are all digging these changes. Up to now I've just been shooting first and delaying questions til later, but it's probably time for a clarifying convo. I'm sure they'll be open to discussion (good vibes all round), but how do you folks approach this stuff?

I'm not looking for additional fee - this work obviously takes a lot longer than straightforward "mixing", but I've always done it without prior conversation so that's for me to deal with. However, in instances like these do you discuss credits for prod / co-prod / ad prod? Or is this just what modern mixing is and I didn't get the memo? Can perhaps DM comparison for reference. There's some obvious ego and division of labour boundaries to be mindful of, and in the end might not be worth it?

author: Rob Domos
content:
I went down a crazy deep rabbit hole about why different EQ’s sound different and after reading a dummy amount of math papers it now makes sense to me. The bonus is that after knowing what to listen for it becomes easier to distinguish and you can choose different EQ’s for different tasks more intelligently. 

In short, when a developer is designing a filter they have to balance between a bunch of different math trade offs. Different math decisions will get you different amounts of ripple, ringing, attenuation, phase delay vs group delay differential, etc. Every compromise imparts a different kind of shittiness. 

To hear two filters that are optimized for absolutely opposite aspects, pull up cleansweep, lowpass something pretty hard, and switch the LPF back and from being a chebyshev filter to being bessel filter.  

With eyes open one would be tempted to explain the differences entirely as being related to the amplitude ripple differences, but with eyes closed instead of just looking at the filter diagram you’ll hear more time domain smearing in the chebyshev as well. 

I’m planning on making an educational video on filter topologies if I can ever get around to it.

author: cian riordan

Both of those instruments are difficult to record properly, and featuring the acoustic nuance of a shitty sm57/Scarlett cello performance won’t do the song justice. I often find I’m compensating for un-ideal mic’ing in un-ideal rooms. I’m doing big midrange scoops to hash out resonances. Driving them into realistic spaces to get the dimension right. Sometimes saturating the source, sometimes saturating the space. The space is everything with orchestral instruments. Every now and then you get a good section in a great room playing a beautiful part and you don’t do a damn thing because it already makes the song.

author: sethearnest
content:
The Way to Export All Tracks from Logic to Equal the Exact Mix that the Artist/Producer Left Off From™

1. Any busses you want printed need to be showing as "tracks" in the Arrange window. You can do this from your Mix Window by selecting all busses/auxes you want to print, right-click, choose "Create Track", and now those Busses/Auxes will show up in your Arrange Window. Do this for any and all effects, parallel busses, etc etc

2. ignore step 2

3. Turn on your Cycle range you want to export (yellow bar across the top like Marv said) and select all tracks you want to export

4. File --> Export --> All Tracks as Audio Files

5. If next dialog box doesn't have options showing, smash that Options Button and choose various options
  a. Range: Export Cycle Range Only
  b. Uncheck "Bypass Effects Plug-ins" if you want their processing
  b. Include Audio Tail and Include Volume/Pan Automation selected
  c. Normalize Off

6. I suggest making an AES-Standardly-named New Folder and exporting into that 

7. Export that bad boy

This will ensure you can import into your Industry Standard DAW exactly where they left off, minus the mix bus processing. 

If they're sharing effects (e.g. guitar and vocal both going to a verb), and you want them both wet but also separate, then they'll need bounce those separately or dup the verb send/return (in which case their Valhalla Vintage Verb will be 12dB too loud b/c they'll forget to turn off their 2bus processing when they bounce it separately)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Cian’s note on pokey frequencies is great. I mix banjo a lot (country music,) and I’ve got a couple thoughts that might be helpful if you’re not already finished. 
1) choose the top carefully. Where the “brightness” of the track is changes so much of how it’s perceived in the track. Chances are the top end is actually much lower than you’d expect. 
2) try compressing the shit out of it. Squash it allll to hell, kill the dynamics, RUIN the performance. There’s a good chance if it’s performed well it’ll turn into a punchy percussive element that adds size and excitement. 
3) make sure it’s balanced with another instrument on the other side of the the stereo field. If you don’t have one that’s playing something similar or has a similar top end, give it the old mono-verb/delay and see if that helps balance and keep it from being too distracting.
Hope that helps!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also, if you’ve already mixed the track, I’d be thinking to make sped up versions of both the source material (played back through your existing chains) AND committed versions of your original BPM tracks. Not to mention your return FX - verb times and predelay might need to be tweaked, possibly delay feedbacks etc. Everything’s going to change, and keeping convincing/good feeling stereo image in things like verbs is one of the challenges.

It’s hard to predict what’s going to happen in any case, so for me it’s about doing the science with your science hat on, taking a break, then fucking around with options until the voodoo clicks. 

It’s not the same mix or even really the same production at the new tempo - groove will change, relationship between rhythmic parts (the satisfying low end you fought for in the kick is suddenly slowing everything down) and consequently vocal parts and their associated time based effects all shifts.

And with all that said: sometimes just blasting your printed mix with soundshifter sync mode beats everything I just described 🤷🏻‍♂️

Sometimes I feel that what I like is that those patches are a little bit over the top but I never bother to edit them because it’s a PITA to do. Maybe with plugins we have too many opportunities to tweak em to “blend” in the mix when the opposite might be better.

Here are a few things I like to do with vocal FX:
- Chorus / Doubler that I then distort and will boost some high mid frequency (spectre is great for that)
- mono slap back is underrated, can be very appropriate in modern mixes
- Mentioned many times but compressing / distorting / EQing reverb returns (side chaining the compressor in the return with the dry vocal as key can really make vocal reverb bloom)
- Also, I don’t always tempo sync my delays, sometimes 300ms just works

author: chrissorem
content: Lots of good  ideas on the mix bus talk!  I think it can be easy to get in the weeds with the “Mix Buss”  I’ve found for myself that I will try these different techniques over the years for example,no mix buss treatment and only a limiter.  Then I tried the music/vocal buss thing. Then I tried only processing the groups and lighter on then mix buss processing.  What I learned is there is no right or wrong way to do anything  and it’s good to try different approaches out but if you feel you are fighting something it’s a good idea to check the processing and see if it’s tying your hands. The only way I know how to do this is gain match your inserts and turn them on and off.   I’ve mixed with the inflator and had good results,  and it’s also been horrible. I’ve mixed with Vulfcomp on the master (generally a horrible idea  but in certain cases it rules!) I even mixed with altiverb on the mix buss recently.  Good technique is  very important but sometimes I like mixing into something wildly colorful and it can take you to very interesting places sometimes you have to work harder for it but the end result can very unique

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: chrissorem
content: This is interesting, I do agree there are  often times decisions aren’t being made. I find that this is a side effect of everyone having the ability to be able to record from their home or wherever. It’s becoming more rare to have a record made with the traditional producer/engineer team working on a record From beginning to end. It’s more common a band will come in and track basics take it home for a few weeks try a bunch stuff out in their untreated room where they really can’t tell if they are adding something to the arrangement that’s muddying up a the song or if it  needs a different mic, positioning or eq ect. This is where I disagree with the whole “they’ve been living with it for however long so just make everything better than what they had”. So even though I might get push back I’m going to try to do whatever  it is I think will make the mix better even if it’s crossing over into  the role of production. author: jerikcenteno
content:
Heyo! I work in podcasting as a freelancer and at a podcast/media company. 

Echoing what others have said — get Hush. Get the one that goes in PT and not the standalone app. It’s expensive and can take a very long time to render if you don’t have a lot of RAM, but it is the best thing ever. Some RX stuff for de-reverbing is too artifact-y. 

Either than that, I just approach it like a regular mix! Go to the part where it looks the loudest and busies, and just make sure all the VO’s are about the same level — just “ear-balling” and clip gaining accordingly. The only diff is I use vocal ride from Waves. 

Also, the company I freelance at asks for final files to be -16 LUFS. Not sure if that’s standard everywhere, but just get a limiter where you can read the final LUFS after committing. 

Another tip is I make sure my clip gaining is set to 3.0dB in preferences. If somebody laughs over somebody, I’ll clip gain it down anywhere from 3-6dB.

author: Moses Mastering
content:
As a mastering engineer, I’ve kept my monitoring level consistent for the past ten years—at a relatively low volume. This isn’t a rule, just my approach, and I do it because I know exactly how a finished track should sound in my room at that level.

Every system has a sweet spot, and if you can identify that in your setup, you’ll get more consistent results. This ties into factors like speaker and amp combinations, how your speakers push air—especially in the low end—and how they perform at different volumes.

Many speakers don’t reproduce low frequencies accurately when played too softly. On the flip side, when pushed too hard, speakers often cap the low end, meaning the bass stops getting louder while the mids and highs continue increasing. This is common in everyday listening setups—people crank their systems beyond their limits, causing an imbalance where the top end dominates.

This is one reason why working with a mastering engineer with a well-calibrated setup can be beneficial. But that doesn’t mean there’s only one way to do things—some engineers work in less-than-ideal setups and still get great results. It all comes down to what works for you and gets you the sound you like.

One thing that’s important to remember which i amsure you already know.... your ears perceive frequencies differently at different volumes—this is a well-documented, non-linear effect. The way we hear balance changes with loudness, which is why understanding how your room and speakers respond at your chosen listening level can make a huge difference in achieving consistent, reliable masters. If you crank it... "memorize" in your ears how it should sound cranked. Then when you drop down to another level.."memorize" how it sounds there. You should then find a few spots you can use.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Certain group processing is easy, e.g. an EQ on a group is mathematically identical to the same EQ on each individual track.

Certain processing (e.g. Autotune) has to be monophonic in order to work right

Certain processing (dynamics, distortion) is very situation-dependent. And the more complex the chain, the more situation-dependent it becomes. And the linear processing (e.g. the EQ, but also most reverbs) then becomes different depending on whether it's before or after the nonlinear stuff.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'd have a talk with the artist - if you haven't already - and get a feel for whether they want to keep it naturalistic (don't touch my performance!) or if they want to juice the sounds and have fun with the sonics - reverb moves, compression effects, weird balance proportions, fader rides, etc.

Without hearing the record, the risk with a lot of noise music is that it gets same-y. So dynamics and sonic interest are your friend. If you can find ways to create contrast and change over 30 second intervals that will go a long way towards engaging the listener. Then again, let's assume that the artist knows what they're doing and has it the way that they want.

If possible, I think it would be fun to invite them in to the mix session and collaborate on the mix with them sitting next to you. Go wild and see what inspires them! Make it into a performance and vibe off of the noise. That might be unorthodox when it comes to mixing records these days, but there's nothing orthodox about this stuff, so have fun!

author: chrissorem
content: @Slow Hand I almost always eq all fx and almost always make a a new verb or delay for  every new instance.  I can’t really think of a reason why I’d share fx unless I want something to melt together.  The fx end  up routing to their prospective group, for example vocal verb would go to vocal group ect and can be processed together if needed. I would almost never insert a verb on an individual track unless I want to push track back more into the mix. Or if I want a verb throw that simultaneously  turns the track down as I turn the verb up.  This is also the primary reason I don’t like inserting fx on a individual track. If you turn the fx up you are also Turing the dry down and in most cases I’m not trying do that. Also tend to process my fx, sometimes compression or saturation and also sometimes send fx to other fx. Example a delay feeding a verb

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Defer to mixers on this (it’s been a long time since I mixed a track), but something to consider:

Use a send when you want to “get at” the reverb itself, process it only, adjust its level only, etc. used to like that a lot workflow wise for my brain.

Sometimes you may only send a single thing to that reverb, or you may send multiple.

Also consider that you need contrast to hear a reverb prominently — if everything has reverb, less contrast.

author: bryan cook
content:
My go to is a 16th note. It may sound like too much when the verb return is loud but when you sink the verb down it usually is really effective for me.

I like to use a mono aux with a delay plug-in for predelays, with a bus as the input and a bus to the verb as the output. No predelay on the verb itself, you make it before hand on this aux. Reason for this being you have a lot of control on your send signal that only the verb hears. A midrangey verb and a full range dry vocal make for depth and texture that can peacefully co exist. You can de ess the send harder than the real LV. With this pre delay aux you can make the send signal darker or brighter. If the song calls for it, make a second aux and have multiple predelays feeding the same verb. For example, a 16th with no feedback that is 80% wet, and a second input bus to same output bus that is dark 1/4 note 100% wet and with feedback where you can automate the send to that long feedback predelay and leave the short no feedback 1/16 static. You can get a lot of mileage out of the same verb with these multiple pre delays and provide some cohesive varied space.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I'm mixing in Ableton and it's a love/hate relationship.  Echoing @Slow Hand, the Audio Effect Rack is so handy for mixing, creating parallel processing chains really easily, and I've also switched away from using sends and returns whenever I can in favor of setting up parallel chains in the Audio Effect Rack which makes printing stems a lot easier or A/Bing processing chains.  I also really like the User Library in Ableton for creating presets and macros of common processing chains I use.

That being said, if I were starting again in a DAW I would have switched to something else a long time ago for mixing.  There are some quirks that I've encountered with the way CPU is handled especially when you get into tracks that push super high track counts.  But I have had a hard time moving away from it just from familiarity, and they've slowly been adding features over the years that make it a little easier as a post-production DAW (groups, take lanes, linking tracks for editing, better templating tools).  But it's the opposite of lightweight and it can be unpredictably buggy when you are pushing the DAW into really high track counts.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’ve got the right idea - The more different the left and right, the more wide it will feel. So you can change timing, pitch, and timbre/tone when double tracking to make it wide but also balanced. For example, double tracking guitars, keep the same guitar cab and guitar but different amp head. Or different pickups from the same entire rig. Etc. 

There have been a lot of good tips for layering vocals, to have the harmonies be different mics and preamps or simply stepping away from the mic to get more distance. 

As far as plugins and stereoizing, even a simple pitch shift plugin can do a lot. Delay 15-30ms each side, pitch +/- 5-10 cents, can get a cool effect if used subtly

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not sure if this is more #📺episode-talk, but there was chat in a recent pod about finding a good Audiomovers / remote mix notes session workflow. I've been having pretty smooth results since 2020 like this:


- Get clients on headphones (unfortunately a necessity for feedback/delay reasons, but I'm finding a lot of times that's how they listen to most music anyway, so they're very familiar with their headphones of choice). 

- Have them open your Audiomovers link.

 - Start a Facetime/Zoom call on your phone with whoever needs to be there. Mute your own Facetime mic on your phone, but clients leave theirs open. They'll hear your chat via the talkback mic you've set up in Tools.

 - Use talkback mic routing as pictured. If you're a Pro Tools nerd, you can probably work out what's going on by following the routing and sidechain assignments in the screenshot, but:


I print mixes and the limited ref (usually just tickling Pro-L 2) at the same time, so I make a Pre-Fade send to the Audiomovers bus from my Mix Print channel. This is also where the limiter lives, so their Audiomovers feed goes out at a healthy level.

My talkback channel (usually a 57) has a ducking compressor on it, sidechained from the Listen Print send and set to stun. This means my TB mic gets (more or less) muted during playback, so I can work on speakers while I make their tweaks. Muteomatic is still in my template, but I think I opted for the sidechained compressor because delay tails etc were getting double piped down to clients through my mic the moment playback stopped, whereas the compressor has adjustable release so it can come back up more or less as the tails die.

If any of that doesn't make sense, just lemme know and I can amend this post.

author: spectrummasters
content: Fwiw , I am sure some plug ins don’t report their latency to your daw correctly and you have to be v careful . I know event horizon clipper in logic would do this . I’ll also  occasionally close the daw completely and reopen the program if I sense there’s any slight delay compensation issues in my mind I’m forcing it to re do all the maths on re opening the project (🤷🏼‍♂️lol) , the other thing I’m careful of is building chains as I get into the mix and then start switching plugs in and out or dragging their orders around too much too late in the mix , I’m sure this is when the maths gets a bit hectic . That’s probably me jus being superstitious on the last one . Logic time delay compensation isn’t where I’d want it to be personally (even paralleling is a bit dicey sometimes ) . It’s by doing these things I’ve been able to pretty much dissolve the “change of pocket “ feel you’re on about and I know v well . Also , I learnt recently that apparently in logic when you bounce all the latencies are more tightly corrected and it comes back together as tight as it ever was , but I work hybrid so that’s no good to me . Anyway good luck . Delay compensation can be a real limiter on mix decisions imo

“This held true over into the recording world for me as well. I came into mixing from mixing my own productions where it was always just making the sound I want. Currently here in London a lot of young rappers like this huge ambient reverb sound for their vocal  that to my ear just leaves a long washyness over the instrumental and I find very hard to accept as appropriate for the groove/tempo and on a rhythmic .delivery ... I think it sounds better dry ...learning how to successfully achieve an aesthetic I disagree with  , to someone else’s satisfaction has been a really rewarding journey of self as well as skill. author: Deleted User
content:
Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand. 

AVOX duo is a neat trick I use sometimes to help give a vocal some dimension. I use it on a send.

author: sukhuno
content:
Yeah dude - it has essentially all of the features of ValhallaDelay already built in... so how i do it is I find the right time pocket (1/4, 1/8, etc) and then set it up in a rack. Then i will mess w the EQ settings of the delay signal to give it the right freq content. I personally only use the ping pong and stereo modes (never really use the M/S). 

Then in the third tab i set up the ducking  and mess with the threshold and release settings to duck out of the way of the lead. I love the sound of the echo swelling up after the phrase is done so i'll usually start at -15 for theshold and ~100ms for release and experiment from there. that third tab also has noise, gate, and a wobble option to add some more character. Then just like the diffusion setting in valhalladelay - you can use the reverb and decay settings to add verb to the delay signal pre/on feedback/post in the chain to give it more softness/space. 

But the killer feature is then you can modulate these settings in the 2nd tab... then i add a little percentage change to one side of the ping pong delay ~1.3% so it's not completely locked in and just adjust settings from there. on the first page, you can also drive the input super hard to get a distorted sound and bring down the output level (like a preamp). It's super versatile and you can get big swelling verb echoes or overdrive space echo type sounds.

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason that analog synths have so much more solid of a lowend than any digital synth. It’s not the saturation giving you that solidity. It’s that hardware LPFs don’t have anywhere near the same amount of cascading delay differential. I.e. a software bass synth by default has a slight reverb that is phase canceling itself wellllllll into the passband (like all the way down iirc) just by the nature of it having a digital LPF bottlenecked at 44.1, where a moog filter has very little of that going on because the sample rate of the real world is infinite, or the speed of light, depending on how you look at it.

author: chrissorem
content: It depends but two things come to mind. One would be that I want to vocal to feel upfront but I want length  I tend to darken with a shelf anywhere from 2-5k. Reduce to taste. I prefer to do this before the reverb usually.  The other thing that comes to mind is verbs can take up quite a bit of space, so  one way to listen for it is to turn the send up to taste and then mute it.  try and listen for what tonal changes are happening when it’s unmuted. And take away masking frequencies.  Some instances I boost frequencies  on the fx  return, this allows it to poke out where it can be heard and I can turn it the return down a bit.  Does that make sense ?

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you've got the *Valhalla Supermassive* I like to make a faux room sound by cranking the *feedback* up to 75%, dialing the *delay time* down to around 9 ms and maybe *warp* at 50%. It's a much more synthetic, and chorus-y sound, but blends well with just about anything.

The cool thing about *Supermassive* is that there's so much heavy modulation on the delay lines that you don't get a lot of nasty ringing or notches that you'd get with most delays at that short of a delay setting.

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I made it up. Take a synth for example. Set up a parallel send bus. Put the panner on the send. I usually compress it to smithereens. Blend it in underneath the main signal. You can get a lot of cool subtle movement. That can fill in the audio spectrum nicely. As example above could use subtle movement to fill out a pad. Or there are more adventurous circular 3D panning options that I find work well top end arps or vox chops. It was an idea born out of how people use 1/8 ping pong delays to fill out behind Bass guitar. Basically a different way to have the audio swim around subtly behind the main source. Try it. It's fun

author: Maxim
content:
It depends on the song but a lot of times you don’t actually want to “hear” the reverb. It should be woven into the performance in a smart way and that’s where choosing the right verb and EQ is essential. 

So I’m not sure if there’s really any “secret” other than developing your ears to hear what’s right and knowing how to get there. 

If a client is asking for “more reverb” I wouldn’t take that literally. Maybe they want to hear more reverb between phrases (automate or use ducking), maybe they want a verb that has more high-end information (plates tend to sound a bit dull unless EQed), maybe use multiple reverbs at different lengths with various characters to compliment each other, etc. etc.

There’s really too many options to give a general response.

But as far as getting the vocal upfront use pre-delay and slap delays to get that width. Dial in the MS amount by ear.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'll bite. Delay lines and feedback loops (the building blocks of a delay unit) have massive utility in audio DSP. With a simple delay unit you can:

Adjust phase relationships
Construct a filter (LPF, HPF, EQ band, etc)
Create echoes
Create chorusing
Create phasing and flanging
Create a tuned resonator
Build a non-granular pitch shifter (think a whammy pedal or a boss shifter)
Build a network of interconnected delay lines and thus a reverb unit

There are plenty more use cases that are slipping my mind right now so.... delay till I die.

Then you can fold all those delay tracks up inside a stack/ folder. Gives more control over the exact timing of when the throws start etc too

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nope. Try this sometime: 

Engage *warp* on the audio file you want to affect. Set it to *Beats* mode. Then, beneath where it says "preserve transients" click the drop down menu with the little arrows and choose the preset with a single arrow pointing to the right.

Now adjust the slider to the right of that menu that goes from *0-100*. As you drag that slider to values lower than 100 all of the ambience tails in between notes will be diminished. That should be a good start to mitigating the reverb.

author: Adam Thein

I'll just chime in to say I've tried Landr on a couple occasions and have always gone back to Audiomovers for the audio quality and sync reasons - could just be my clients and their internet situation but ListenTo has more flexibility with what codec you are broadcasting so if your client is on their phone you can send them 128kbps AAC or if they are on their monitors or a good listening environment using push to talk you can send them 24bit WAV. The other side perk of using Audiomovers is I'll just ask what video chat software the other person wants to use - using whatever they're familiar with (Google Meet/Zoom/Facetime, whatever)

author: GaspardMurph
content: Hey Chad, thanks for the video! I use the same technique as well. In my experience and after much testing, I have found that buffer size makes NO DIFFERENCE in h/w insert latency (at least with my Apollo interfaces, could be different with others but not sure why). Also, I had my HW latency dialed perfectly for each sample rate I use but since the second to last PT update (the one before integrated Melodyne), I have found that pro tools now calculates automatically and if I leave all HW latency at 0.0 in my playback engine, I get perfect null). Also! I have found that one thing that totally affects the number of delay is the settings of my interface, there are a bunch of settings within the Apollo’s (dsp load lock, UAD engine delay comp…) that will affect the latency. Hope this information might help!

author: GaspardMurph
content: Also worth noting that I did the null test in another studio a year ago that runs PT HDX with Lynx converters and it wasn’t a sample accurate null, delay still needed to be calculated and entered in the playback engine.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If I'm totally rebalancing drums, I'll treat them as if I'm tracking them myself and building a basic working drum sound.This *usually* goes as follows, and I like to do it *very* quickly (as if the drummer is in the live room playing and everyone's waiting):

1. Mute everything.
2. Pull up kick in and out (+ sub or whatever they've recorded). Play with balance and phase of kick out until it feels good (good is context dependent - sometimes that's deep/subby/slow, sometimes that's punchy/percussive etc).
4. Bring up overheads along with kick mics. Flip overhead phase and play with balance til it sounds cool, or punchy, or whatever you're after. Sometimes there's a very obvious right or wrong answer, but often just figure out whatever works for the drum groove + arrangement + song. Where the bass sits can often help tell you what config will work best.
5. Solo snare mics, get them in phase with each other (just listen together and flip usually snare bottom until the blend sounds cool to you - often I'm looking for whichever configuration has more "thud", but that's context dependent). 
6.Unsolo and check snares against kicks and overheads. If you need to flip the snares, flip both top and bottom (or whatever combo) together so their relative phase remains intact. 
6. Add in rooms, again flipping and balancing til shit feels cool. Do same for crush mics, any other flavour stuff.

Toms are usually my last concern. Unless the groove is tom heavy, they might do only 2 or 3 hits across the whole song, so as Ryan said - hand gate those fuckers and deal with them once the general sound is dialled in.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m dealing with this on a friend’s movie right now. The producer kept asking for a sound to have less reverb. Demanded it. Too much reverb. Every mix.

Turns out by reverb they meant tremolo on a synth track. 

You can’t expect not audio nerds to understand how to talk about audio the way we do. You’re far far far better off like Rauari says getting them to explain the symptom, and building the trust to let you come up with the solution. Otherwise you’re going to get “.2db notes from people who have no actual idea what .2db sounds like. You’re making the move they asked for, instead of what they actually want.

author: cian riordan
content:
1. I assume you’re talking about multiple mics/tracks of the same source and checking the phase relationship between? If so, I never do this. I’ll usually re-balance the two tracks I’m hearing so they’re equal volume before trying to make a decision.
2. Surely. It works well for transient rich stuff like drums… less so for guitars/basses/keys… etc.
3. Some folks manually adjust the track and it can get dangerous if you’re mismanaging your clips…. I find using a plugin is a more fool-proof way of making these adjustments. I used to just use the stock time-adjuster in Pro Tools but lately I’ve been using the Eventide Precision Time Align because it allows you to move forward and backwards, as well as course vs. micro adjustments.

author: Adam Thein
content: I like to reach for brighter verbs in this kind of scenario - something with some texture like a spring or a plate or a digital verb with some texture.  Start there, mess with the width of it first.  Generally think if it more as a synth pad layer.  Emphasizing 2-5k if it really needs to cut with spectre or Saturn or a brighter saturation.  Using a delay in combination so that the decay envelope has some movement so my ear latches onto it more.  Panning, modulation, tremolo, etc, subtle ways to grab attention even at low level.  And good old volume automation.  Printing the verb can help give you some visual feedback for how it’s decaying.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Would be interested to hear a counter argument, but here’s my take. 

I used to do have a whole template where Vox FX were the only things actually bussed together. 

But over time I’ve realized I use aux sends fx very sparingly. Most of the verbs or delays I’m using are equally as effective on the track with the mix knob, and then all the fx processing is right there on the channel etc. there are downsides but this speeds up the workflow a lot.

author: chrissorem
content: I do analog summing when I mix so  I have daw  groups that feed final daw  output groups that feed my console. Generally I try to not share fx between groups and designated fx that feed the groups. Example: vocal verb or delays outputs go to vocal group. This give an option to eq compress or saturate and melt together if intended. If I don’t want that I send the fx to their final outputs. Example: vocal verb output doesn’t go to vocal Group but to vocal output to console. This is a good workflow for making stems ect as well.

author: chrissorem
content: There is no right or wrong way if it’s sounds good it is good. But keep in mind that if you have a verb or delay inserted on a channel and you are using the mix knob. The more you turn the mix knob up the more you are Turing the original source down. If you use a send  rather that doesn’t happen

author: Adam Thein
content:
I see - what I’m thinking is maybe this step could be working against you - you are essentially forcing all your mics to sum perfectly and you might be ending up with having to do massive eq moves on things that maybe would have naturally been phasing out in a pleasing way for a live room recording.

I’d strongly consider turning off your AA2 plugs on anything that aren’t drums unless it makes it sound significantly worse to you.

I’m a big fan of AA2 but it’s always case by case.  Sometimes the natural phase of the mics can be closer to the result you are looking for eq wise than the perfectly time aligned and phase rotated ones.

author: Marc
content:
For reference tracks — I was curious to compare two songs I love Bowie’s “Young Americans” and Springsteen “10th Avenue Freeze Out”. Similar instrumentation but the lesson for me was size and prominence of the different instruments. Bowie’s bass is way more prominent than Bruce. Bruce has the piano and guitar up front. Bowie’s has more delay and reverb. 

I think it reminds me I have to make more choices, and I also —(have to write better songs lol) — have to keep in mind when I use a reference track, that my tonal balance may be different or the vocal will sit differently if, say, my snare is way fatter/thinner than the reference track or my lead vocal is in a different octave register, which means the guitars are competing etc.

author: cian riordan
content: So to clarify, I will sometimes use HPF to solve for phase issues between multiple drums mics. The prime example of this is if I have a kit or a room mic that is in phase with the snare drum but out of phase with the kick drum. Sometimes, using the targeted phase shift of a HPF, you can find a way to get both fundamentals to pop into phase on the offending microphone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So I'm hearing two things: You're having difficulty knowing how to get what you want (over or under processing) and you're not feeling confident about the choices that you're making.

If you hadn't already mentioned it, my first thought would be to evaluate your monitoring because it sounds as if you're missing the mark that you're aiming at (over/under processing). But it also sounds like you are split on the target that you're trying to hit in the first place.

When the production you're given to mix is lacking in some way - maybe the sonics aren't great, the arrangement isn't great, or the song is not great - there can be an urge as mixer to want to close that gap by delivering a killer mix. Sometimes we see that gap and think that we'll be able to make this record amazing and make up for it's shortcomings by crushing the mix. But there's only so far that we can take a song at the mix stage. Maybe the record will be great anyways despite some perceived issue.

While there's always room for improvement take care that you're not putting all of that weight on your shoulders. By all means do a great job, but know when to stop chasing an unattainable goal. It's not necessarily something that you can resolve as mixer. So - if that's the case - make sure you're not demanding the world from yourself.
