author: jerikcenteno
content:
OH! Thought of two more things that I feel is important to add that ppl might find helpful....

Definitely strip silence/cut out silences in the non-talking audio to get rid of the noise floor, coughs, etc. I do this by hand rather than the strip silence function since the function in PT might delete stuff I didn't want deleted.

At the company I freelance at, they heavily use this app called Descript. You upload your VO's and it builds out a transcript for you. You then can edit the transcript and it'll chop up the audio accordingly. It works better when the VO's are isolated/have no bleed and not recorded in the same room because bleed can mess up the transcription, but if Descript is analzying just one VO at a time, it works great. Then, you can export an .aaf and upload into PT to make fades, mix, etc. Check it out! I've used it too and it's kinda crazy. Prob the only useful AI thing I've come across. 

https://www.descript.com/

author: jerikcenteno
content:
Oh I hear you! When I freelance produce AND edit/mix, it takes a LONG time. Basically, 90mins+ would take me all day right up until dinner. But yeah, I would do it all in one sitting. I remember early on, I'd start at like 9:30AM/10AM and I'd probably be exporting a bounce at about 7PM. 

At the company I work/freelance at, they have dedicated producers to give notes with timecodes, so the audio engineers (me), our job is to just assemble the show (cuz they record segmenets at diff times), mix it, and clean things up so to speak. Then, the producers QC it and give more notes and see if they wanna cut anythign else on top of what they initially noted.

I echo what @Brendan Trinkle as it actually taking 4x the runtime. IME, that's what it looked like for me. With having a dedicated producer who's taking notes in real time from the recording, it's much faster. 

But yeah, it's a growing pain if you don't have notes. If somebody is gonna QC it, it may be worth the while to just do a "quick" pass and have them listen to what they wanna tighten up/chop out. I think what got me faster when I was proucing and editing was not being so nit picky about cutting "ums" and trying to put myself into "listener" mode. 

Try to check out Descript. It might help you out seeing everything and making giant content cuts accordingly. That was the hard part early on for me while producing + editing was not knowing if bits would come back later on in the recording or not.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @sinaigimenez You can go very scientific with this, but first thing I would do is find a handful of your favourite tracks and play them back at a level where you feel comfortable in your room - not too loud that it hurts, but feels relatively balanced.  Then use a quick SPL Meter in C weighted mode (loads available for iphone) and see where the SPL lands when playing back these tracks.  In my room it's around 75-80 db and I'm comfortable there.  I know that when I leave my monitor controller at my predetermined setting playing back mastered -9>Lufs tracks roughly how it should sound.  if something sounds dark/bright it's usually because it is.  Like wise if a vocal is too quiet, I'm not reaching for the main volume pot to turn the overall mix up, I'm turning the vocal up until it feels right.  And also, if my mix isn’t feeling loud enough or present enough at the preset monitoring level I know I need to work harder to get it to sit in the same world as the refs.  Once you get your head around it, it’s very freeing.  I use Metric Halo Monitor controller directly connected to my speakers and control via a Stremdeck (thanks @Bryan DiMaio !) and this has 5db volume steps where I know I can mix without my limiter at +10 and when the limiter is engaged I need to be back at 0. I imagine the Hilo has something similar?

author: JustinLeu
content:
There is so much great info on this discord re:drum mixing but what @chrissorem just highlighted is so key. A lot of the times when people track drums, it is common to track many more microphones than are used in the actual mix down. 

The idea is that if you track multiple songs in a session you won’t have to set-up more mics as you go, you are just ready for most styles with one mic setup. (maybe you use brushes on a more chill track…or as a layer etc) maybe in mixdown you want a super vibey room thing, or maybe you want really tight Phoneix style.

author: spookydrums
content: An IR is also a static image of a dynamic thing (which makes me think of the lyric «recorded music is a statue of a waterfall» from last year’s Mount Eerie record), so to me it actually feels less realistic in a way, a very reduced version of a highly complex thing. It definitely has it’s uses though! But like for instance if you think of sound being transmitted through a spring in a spring reverb, every impulse will hit the spring on a different part of the spring’s travel from side to side and will impact how the vibrations transmit through it in such a complex way, while every time an impulse hits the spring reverb IR it will be «transmitted»  from the same starting point

author: wcalebparker
content:
With regard to the “practicing new concepts” thing - for me it depends on the situation. The other day I was working on a live thing and I needed to deal with some bleed. My usual tools weren’t cutting it, so I spent a little time digging into another tool which I thought might do the job well. The deadline isn’t particularly tight so I had the leisure.

I think depending on where you are in your career, it can be really helpful to use someone else’s mixing philosophy as a learning tool, but if people are coming to you for what you do, client projects are probably not the time for that.  

In my head there’s a pretty big difference between exploring a new reverb plug to potentially generate some inspiration and deciding, “on this project I’m SIDE-CHAINING EVERYTHING” when that hasn’t been your thing in the past.

But also, I don’t really think about this that much, and I think you’ll probably have to develop your own feel for what’s appropriate for you. But I wouldn’t  recommend watching MWTM and changing your entire workflow mid project (although I’ve admittedly done this in the past 😂)

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Another primary thing that makes EDM records sound different from rock is that pretty much nothing in EDM has any room tone. Samples are generally dry, and if there’s any reverbs it’s generally algorithmic. 

I’d work on ways to reduce any room tone, be it EQing out modes, turning down distant mics, using transient shapers to decrease the sustain, etc

author: h3x
content: The way the human ear perceives “more reverb” is through a longer pre-delay. The decay is the ringing out of said reverb. Turning it up is just the volume of said reverb. Pre-delay is super important to fit in the pocket so that u dont need to turn it up loud to feel/hear the reflections and separation

author: Shadowherb
content: i think the unfortunate truth is that asymmetrical mixes translate way better through speakers than through headphones, and most ppl these days listen to music through headphones. still, i love asymmetrical mixes. for hardpanned drums, look no further than Beatles' "Taxman". also, if you want a masterclass on tasteful assymetrical mixing, check out any stereo mixes Rudy Van Gelder made for Blue Note. what he'll often do is hardpan all the drum mics to the right channel and hardpan the room mic to the left channel. that way, even though the mix is heavily weighted to one side, there's a sense of a united stereo field that ties it all together

author: Deleted User
content: In my experience, double tracking the exact same instrument - like the same guitar - will usually just end up sounding phasey, not thick and wide. You really really want it to be 2 different guitars, using a different amp or EQ just doesn’t really cut it, I find. And preferably also different amps and maybe even mics on the speakers. The more you’re actually close to something that could literally be an acoustic event(meaning it could play out that way if you were recording both parts live simultaneously), the less phasey it will be. If vocal doubles are too close to the lead sonically, for example, they can end up sounding like a phasey reverb instead of adding punch. So definitely use a different mic. Like, even Freddie Mercury‘s background vocals can sometimes sound a bit one-dimensional because of this, though of course Queen‘s performances were utterly amazing(it usually was just one u67 they tracked with)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Convolution is a strange technique to describe in a way that is intuitive to understand. But here goes:

In convolution you have two audio signals, your *input signal* and your *impulse response*. The simplest description of what convolution does is that it multiplies the *input* signal by the *impulse* signal and what it spits out is a new audio signal that includes only the frequencies and amplitude values that both signals have in common.

Practically speaking, what this means is that when you convolve an *input* (let's say, a full frequency drum kit recording) with your *impulse* (let's say a 5 ms burst of white noise that was hi-passed at 500 Hz). What you end up with is a drum recording that sounds like it was hi-passed at 500 Hz.

Think of it like how a vocoder works (which isn't that different). Your vocoder might combine a full-frequency synthesizer patch (input) with the frequency contours and time content of your voice (impulse/carrier). But if your voice doesn't have 100 Hz in it then we never hear the 100 Hz from the synth patch because the input and carrier/"impulse" don't share that frequency. What you hear is what both signals have in common. If your voice has a huge peak at 1.5k, then the synth patch is going to be accentuated in that same way.

So. What I'm saying is that if I have a complex EQ curve (ala Sonarworks corrective EQ) that I use as my *impulse response* and convolve it with, say, the output of my stereo buss, will it impart that frequency curve onto my mix *without* the phase shift that you'd get from a traditional FIR or IIR filter (aka traditional EQs)?

In short, I don't know because it's hard to search for the answer online. But I'm throwing a hail mary in case we've got any DSP nerds in the forum.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
If it's really upsetting me I might deal with it early, but I prefer to live with those details as I get the drum mix together - there's (usually) going to be bus compression, maybe added fake Oceanway room, samples and their idiosyncracies - so many variables, all often getting processed on drum bus (+ potential parallels per song section).

By the time I'm done with that it usually just feels more like a general vibe than an exercise in precision - the snare ring in the left room mic might draw the ear away from the kick flam in the right (or that flam could now groove in a cool way as the comps breathe, or it slaps against a rhythm guitar part or whatever), but I can always go back and Time Adjuster (or L/R EQ with Fab or whatever) the rooms if they're really bothering me.

Same reason I don't usually address snare rings until I've got the drums working well

author: Ross Fortune
content:
And I totally agree on only doing what sparks joy. I’ve wholly accepted that my only consistent motivator is loving what I’m doing in each moment. 

In every aspect of my life - work, relationships, any decision - any time I’ve gone against my gut and done *anything* for the wrong reason, it’s come back to bite me ten fold. 

I still think the above is a reasonable thought exercise though. We’re artists and creators and all that, but as it stands for most of us we’re businesses too, and human beings. It’s a positive thing to reflect on experience and evaluate potential future positions, if only to be certain you don’t want to go down particular roads. My actual life experience has just been to do what I like to do, and that’s guided me, but maybe there’s room for forward thinking so we don’t wind up down holes we don’t want to be in.

author: Rob Domos
content:
It sounds cloudy, less solid, and like you’re losing texture. 

This largely happens because phase delay and group delay changes imposed by an eq aren’t linearly correlated to each other, so you end up getting a blurring that sounds kind of like a very short and close first reflection

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s always been: if something is crucial to the vibe of the song, say a certain echo, or dotted stereo delay guitar part, that shit gets printed and sent as an option. But the mixer also gets the rough in case they got a better way to do it. 

That’s why a mixer gets a rough bounce. So they know what to reference. 

CLA used to have a 12 page mix submission requirement thing where you had to consolidate all files, take off all fx entirely, and send him all the tracks bounced from 1 clearly labeled.

Again, it’s CRAZY to me watching a mixer pushback against having to actually mix the song. It’s like someone hiring me to vocal produce and I’m like “cool, but you have to pre record the vocals, compress them right, get the takes, comp em, mix them, and then I’ll… tickle them a little. Where’s my 5k and a point?”

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think it’s really important to not confuse a shitty drummer flamming with “phase relationship”. Especially because lining up a snare hit on a live kit to not flam will actually fuck with phase relationships. 

Again the screen shot shows a poor drum hit, not a phase issue per se, which AGAIN was the original point of gaspards post was that he was intermittently flipping phase on certain hits. That’s a very different thing then linking up a snare hit to not flam. 

This kinda feels like when my friend was making a movie and she kept authoritatively and confidently telling the composer to turn down the reverb and after a week in frustration she brought the stems to me and I got to go “oh. You mean tremolo”.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yeah so x/y isn’t great for info on the sides for a solo performance. It’s more about capturing more of the guitar, the string chime and the body. It’s a little wider than a mono mic so it works well as a single instrument with a vocal, but it’s not gonna do a “stereo” thing. 

My best advice out the gate is keep it about 6-8” off the 10th feet and move around until the balance feels right. If you’re missing brilliance, try raising the guitar or leaning left or right a little… it’s really about your instrument and your room and which mics you’ve got. 

Honestly x/y should be an easy way of getting the full guitar captured.

author: Edward Rivera
content:
If you have room mics, you're going to want to delay them in order to simulate the heard experience of the instrument in that room. The mic itself will capture the sound signature of the ambience, but the delay will give the perception of that ambience. 

Think of a drum kit in a room, and you've got a room mic on the far end of said room. The sound of the drum is going to travel across the room and into that mic, but it needs to travel _back_ to the drummer in order to be perceived. That's what the delay will do

author: Rob Domos
content: Voices in room do not sound like they are hitting a microphone. Think about the physics of sound for a second. High frequencies move in a laser beam shape and low frequencies move in a spherical shape. Nobody is ever turning with their ear facing 1 foot from a mouth that is laserbeaming high end into their ears. This is why you almost never hear saliva drips and lip smacking when in conversation and hear it constantly in recordings. This is also a big reason why the high end of most captures sounds so rough and edgy compared to real life. A lot of what I’m doing is going in and massaging that high end to take it from “this sounds like a mic capsule” to “this sounds like the person is in the room”

author: Rob Domos
content:
Some other things you can to create space for them each to sit:

- Move one of them to the sides with something like the stereoize function in the ozone imager. Even just one band wider on one of them could solve the problem. 

- Try something like ST4B to get a different relationship between the transients and sustains of the sounds 

- If all else fails, I sometimes try out a *very* slight tremolo on sustained sounds and it surprisingly consistently cleans up cloudy masking issues. The way I do it the tremolo isn’t noticeable but it still creates a hair more space for the other sounds to pop through. I usually only do this on reverbs and pads, but it *might* work on one of the basses.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

author: cian riordan
content: There will always be a phase interaction if you have two parallel processing chains on a single source. In the case of the amp, there's a physical delay in the sound coming out of the speaker and hitting the microphone. In the case of an amp sim, there's just so many variables there (if its trying to replicate that physical delay, delay compensation, etc). Best to just check that stuff with a phase switch though. I wouldn't dig too much into this HPF idea... it's really solving for a different problem.

author: JustinLeu
content:
That is a frustrating place to be…some clients are more difficult than others and figuring it out a few songs in to a large project is the worst. 

1. Changes that don’t make much of a difference…just do them. There are times that I will communicate if I think we may be “chasing our tail”. There are definitely non-combative ways to let them know it may be hurting the song overall.  I try to remind myself in these situations that we both want the song to be great.

2. Specific to your situation, you mentioned noticing that words he wanted turned up really may need to be turned up. If I’m in that situation I am definitely looking at myself to figure out where and how I’m missing the mark.

3. Working with people that are not used to making professional productions can be tricky. I find that mix notes in those situations can be difficult to navigate, for instance “can you turn down the reverb” ends up being a problem because now they are fixated on that note and “listening for reverb” in which case they just keep hearing it until it is now too low in reality. (Time to communicate kindly that you are “chasing your tail” or similar) 

4. Unless it is someone I really want to work with…I’m not discounting rate for new clients, in fact, I’d suggest that is actually the time to increase your rate if you have been wanting to.

author: Matt Huber

I have used it in occasion…

It’s usually in the context of an arrangement that I want to put into a unified “space.”

The times where it has really worked for me have been things that are supposed to sound “live.”

That said, it’s pretty rare for me. But sometimes it’s the thing that made the performance sound convincing. 

Also, not all reverbs are great at this duty. Seventh Heaven has been a winner for me, though.

It really doesn’t need much to change the feeling

author: JustinLeu

You learn the rules to break them 🙂 if you want it to be creative and have an interesting room sound there is nothing wrong with some verb on the 2 bus. 

Or for more control separate 2-3 pre mixbus groups and put on verb/dly/what ever your rule breaking heart desires. 

If you want you can group specific controls/plugins on those mix groups to make broad changes quickly then disable the group and tweak what you need to.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I find it's rarely necessary to compress a synthesizer if you're the one programming it. You already have control over the attack/sustain ratio on the instrument using the ADSR controls. And you can balance the harmonics through your choice of filtering or oscillators. Synthesizers rarely have low-level information to be revealed that can't simply be turned up at the source.

Of course, you might want the distortion artifacts from compression, but I'd probably use a saturator module.

That said, if you're a mixer who has received an audio bounce of a synth, then... sure! Compression would be good for balancing poke-y stuff, controlling boomy low-end, or there could be some room tone from a re-amp signal, or some attack that needs to be accentuated. So compress away!

author: Juliette
content:
When you're done working on the session for the day, play video games, walk with your dogs, give your brain another outlet to focus on. I've found that when you're in grind mode, your head starts to getting wrapped up and you can feel frustrated and everything in the project starts sounding like a noisy echo chamber.

During the session itself, with crunches, there are going to be points where you're overwhelmed. Take some five minute breathers in silence. It sounds silly but the silence really helps to refocus yourself and help you better understand what you're trying to achieve within the project (at least for myself, haha)

1. You can probably do a lot to improve things in the mix, yes
2. Some of the things you mentioned I would not necessarily expect to be fixable in the mix, regardless of monitoring and regardless of the precision of the EQing. author: bryan cook
content: I have always been from the school of make it sound as finished as possible as early as possible. It doesn’t have to be perfect but it should be close. You never know who is going to walk in the room mid production. Sonic sorting is important for the artist’s psychology but it’s crucial to inform the producer if it needs more or less and in what registers and counter rhythms. This sonic sorting may or may not involve plugins, could just be getting the source right if you have time. But sonic de-cluttering is not a wait for mix thing imho.

author: Deleted User
content: To me personally, throws are more about what effects are followed after. My favorite post delay/reverb effects Unfiltered Audio Byome. For workflow, this is 10/10. It’s a modular multi effect plugin, and making a few different presets on it allows me to quickly switch around between different colors and modulation. It has random parameter set feature and can unexpectedly bring in interesting sounds quickly too. Other than that, I also like Soundtoys stuff for phaser and tremolos, ubermod for chorusing and other phase effects on the delays. For reverb, Dverb is actually pretty cool especially when it’s mixed in with delays. I like Valhalla vintage verb and eventide ultraverb as well. And for post verb or delay saturation, decapitator and spectre. Saturn if I wanna use the dynamics control on it. I also like messing with the polarity, sometimes flipping it can get the presence of the tail heard better without obscuring the dry sound as much.

author: Maxim
content:
I mean without music in context there's not a ton to say. And even if you managed to get the room out of the vocal (which with plugins like RX 8/9, C-VOX, SPL De-Verb, etc. is still not great) I doubt you'd be left with much that's "nice" to work with. 

But nevertheless, after doing some processing with the usual tools (best mentioned above - look into the new Dialog Isolate from RX 9) my intuition would be to eq the lower mids/lows first in the context of the music to get rid of the room "mud". 

Then maybe (lightly) slap some Soothe or Gullfoss on there to see what that does. Then once you've possibly got something to work with, go through the usual steps you might process a vocal with  (more additive/tone-shaping tools to get a sound).

Thing is, if you don't have all these plugins already it would be much cheaper to just record a better vocal. (I think you can demo them all though?) Maybe even consider renting a studio for a day (if the artist has the budget).

This is really valuable! Thanks a lot. To go into some of your questions; I'm using Adam a7's (not the newer a7x's, although I tested them and they're wasn't as much of a difference as I had expected in my room). Any peaks and valleys i did have have been sorted out further as much as possible with sonarworks which has really outdone my expectations. I also use Beyerdynamics dt770 pro's.

I often take as much time just manually leveling a vocal, taking out esses etc as I do mixing. Fresh air and dopamine have indeed been big helpers and have been big steps towards that sizzle. Also the waves exciter in parallel has been working okay.
I never seem to be able to get a multiband compressor to work well. Either I'm overdoing some of the setting or something because often i feel like it attenuates too much and other times to little in the places I want it to. I've noticed that a little boost in the low mids on pro-q3 that then also attenuates dynamically can work. 
Could you go into a bit more detail on what you mean with phase bringing a vocal more forward?
I've also noticed that a lot of the sound I'm looking for comes from a certain sort of rolling kind of sound that might be coming from the rappers throat? I'm not sure at all about this but it seems like it's almost vocal fry but in a very natural way that is inherent to the singers/rappers voice. Idk if this is a rapping technique thing or if this is more accentuated in the mixing process, but it sounds really nice.
Definitely a big thankyou for all the tips!

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a very complex question. 

The closer you get at the beginning to a finished sounding product, the easier each phase gets. More time/effort spent arranging the song, less time recording. More time/effort recording, less needed for mixing, etc. But there just isn’t always the time to make things that “perfect” when you’re in the room with folks producing or writing, etc. 

A conversation on here that was an eye opener: a finished mix should be 99% complete sounding before going to mastering. I wouldn’t intentionally leave a lot of decisions up for the mix phase. 

Honestly, there’s two ways you can go about this. You can revise the production and recording to get it where you want, take as much time as it takes. Or you can try to mix the hell out of it and move on to your next project. There’s always more songs. Finishing is incredibly important.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m not totally sure. I don’t think metering is going to help you. I’d avoid a mix by numbers approach. Maybe your monitoring needs some attention. A bad room can really make it painfully hard to make confident decisions that translate in the moment or even later in mixing.

Templates to me speed up your workflow not necessarily help you make better decisions if that makes sense. It’s like, setting up several busses you ALWAYS make, so instead of doing 100 keystrokes and commands to get your busses and FX built, two clicks and they’re there for you.

I don’t know what genre / style / level you’re working at, but I’d say just keep working at it. I love recording music because you can ALWAYS do it again. Time is the only thing you have to lose. With enough time, anything is possible. 

That said, looking at a frequency analyzer of a whole mix you like isn’t a horrible thing to do. Maybe you’ll see your mix is way too dark, or way too thin simply.

author: Will Melones
content:
Damn you just gave me an idea. I mixed a score once with different PT track folders for each stem, and dedicated reverb/delay returns for each instrument group to keep things separated.

I could offline commit all of the folders at once, and after a couple minutes of rendering I had stems. And in film it’s very important that the stems match *exactly*. BUT there was no master buss processing, intentionally.

But if you were to take your master chain and put it on, say, the last 5 inserts of each folder, identically, and only use dynamics plugins with sidechain inputs, you could feed your mix buss input to the sidechain of all those plugins. Then create a mix group wherein the settings for inserts f-j are linked…

This would obviously be an ITB-restricted solution with a heavy processor load. And I’m not sure how you’d set it up in Reaper, but it’d probably be even better than in Pro Tools

Put the high verb through heavy modulation and it can be a beautiful trip.

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m starting to believe I’m not as good at treating vocals as I thought I was. Usually the stuff I get to mix is recorded in a bedroom or worse on a cheap condenser mic, and I’ll do what I can to polish the turd, but at some point it’s as good as it can get.

But then I listen to some of the previous releases some of these artists have, and I wonder if the folks who mixed those songs had to work with the same quality raw material. The stuff sounds pro in the end (sometimes).

It seems like this is more and more the way things will be for good. It’s rare that someone is singing into a decent mic and pre in a treated room (studio!?) or that they bother with mic technique.

Does anyone have tips or resources related to *really* digging into the repair of things like wonky room resonances, harsh-ass mics, inconsistent distance, and sometimes no talent? It seems like the folks working in that next level up can wave a magic wand and turn an NT1A into a 251 without harshness or dullness.

I always thought vocal recording was pretty clear cut. I guess I spoiled myself because all of the stuff I mixed early on I had recorded myself, and my only real ‘vocal’ mic was an RE20.

author: ehutton21
content:
Ahhh I see you’ve met my people—the bedroom artist! 

Jokes aside, I got into engineering because me and my friend could not afford to have someone decent mix our stuff, so I know the NT1A to 251 struggle well—he records exclusively on an NT1A. 

The biggest thing about working with bedroom-y vocals is they’re going to have their shortcomings, and maybe more so than most other mixes, you can process them quite a bit and you should. Do whatever RX work you need to do, and do that first. I don’t usually worry about playing the vocals with the track at this point, im just hunting for any pops, clicks, clips or room artifacts. 

Next for me is reamping—this may be odd to some people and their may not be a general consensus on how much it helps, but it gives me a sense of tonal consistency when I can set how I want the vocal to drive. If you have something that feels like how you would have tried to record it, it helps the psychological aspect IMO.

author: ehutton21
content: Yeah, it depends. I like room ambience match in RX if I need it and I mean we all know the slog of clip gain, pro-q, clipper, repeat. When it comes to taking something like wild resonances though I like tools that don’t make me overthink, and with soothe and multiband I gain tonal control I can’t gain otherwise

author: Slow Hand
content:
lol. Reminds me of this old Max/MSP device that someone made that compressed audio into something like 2 bits of dynamic range. You could end up with a truly flat audio file that had lost all sense of proportion. A sample of a door slamming in a house might go like this:

1. A tiny tick (door slamming)
2. A period of steady midrange (the room verb)
3. The whoosh of the entire noise floor and A/C unit rushing in to fill the vacuum. 😆

author: Will Melones
content:
If you REALLY want to simulate a soundstage, four zone reverbs with *mostly* similar settings—rear left, rear right, front left, front right. A little darker and longer in the back, and whatever spices up the left/right contrast. Send everybody to all 4 zones, but in varying amounts depending on where they’re ‘standing’. 

I’m imagining this as a relatively acoustic thing, and this approach may not apply to much else…

author: samvalentine
content: My first guess would be the mix has a different verb size (maybe predelay) or delay speed than the rough. Even subtle changes to time-based effects can alter the pocket of a vocal. Compression attack time could also be a culprit. Definitely not unusual to impart subtle pocket changes if you’re doing some heavily lifting in the mix. Don’t be afraid to nudge the whole vocal a bit to solidify the pocket.

author: popaganda.
content: A couple things - there are no “shoulds” in music. Play around until it sounds good. If you have trouble hearing the effects of different reverb settings I would just open up a session, maybe something you’ve already finished, and just play around with the verb settings and listen and see if you can create that sense of depth with early reflections predelay and decay. But my general stance is that if you can’t hear it it doesn’t really matter for this project, and if you want to hear it better you should do some experiments, stretch your ears out, and also maybe see if you need to deal with anything in your room or speakers that’s obscuring the perception of space.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Varies client to client, relationship to relationship. 

Reasons not to overexplain: Let them have their experience, don't put anything in their head. They may just be stoked and then you get the mix approved. 

Working in the Ad-World: They *dont give a FUCK* about your explanation. They just want to see it and if it's good they'll go "awesome. thanks bye we got other shit to do". 

Reasons to explain: 
These people have a hard time letting themselves just experience the song, or if you have a SLEW of revisions, sometimes it's nice to address each one individually. 

Example:

"Turned up the bass, fixed that transition in the prechorus, made the guitars less harsh and more spacy in the verses. let me know how that feels".

Whatever....I think there's strategic and emotional reasons to do both.

author: Zack Hames
content: If someone asks every time you send a mix "so what did you do? What's different?" feel free to explain. most artists don't give a shit if you say "I boosted 2k on the lead vocal, adjusted the pre-delay on the reverb, and side-chained the bass to the kick drum"

Feel like engineering to me is some combo of:

- does this sound the way I want it to?
- does this sound like music?
- does this sound like a record?

Ideally tryna hit all four. Then there's the added dimension of how fast / efficient the engineering was done and how you made everyone in the room feel when doing it.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Is the kick note decaying too slowly?  Like if it decayed faster would it be workable, or are you trying to find a way to move the pitch down?

I’d try a soothe sidechained to an original copy of the kick close mic(s) and try and get that to pull the kick’s decay off the room and overheads, then you can play with repitching the kick close mics depending on bleed or combining with a volume shaper like the Cableguys thing or Duck or LFO Tool, something that can use the audio input as the detection circuit and try and shorten the kick as much as you can get away with and then if you have to layer in something like a clean sine wave gated to the kick to get the note you are looking for.

Definitely not without a lot of tradeoffs on the way but some combination of that has worked for me in the past in a pinch

author: Slow Hand
content: Well I know a lot of digital verbs have crosstalk within their delay networks, so they're kind of woven together. It's probably extra effort to build and fine-tune a delay matrix that works as a single channel.

author: Deleted User
content:
I wonder if folding down the crosstalk into mono version of delay feed will compromise the integrity of the reverb’s character and that’s why they don’t do it. 

When I fold stereo output of reverb into mono, I find that the character of the reverb- or at least my perception of it changes.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. It's rare for a stereo verb to fold down to mono and not shrink. Reverb by it's very nature is incredibly phase-y. You'll get a lot of cancellation when you combine the channels. One thought I've never considered is isolating the mid signal on a stereo verb. I wonder how well that holds up. Gonna try right now.

author: Slow Hand
content: As it turns out, isolating the center on Valhalla Vintage Verb and Seventh Heaven both sounded even *worse* than simply folding down to mono. It sounds sputtery and broken. Odd.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. It's special. I love that they extend the additive synthesis to form the reverb and the echoes too. The amount of control that synth has over the harmonics is soooo cool. And it doesn't ever get bogged down in the minutiae. Brilliant design.

author: Slow Hand
content: So cool. The reverb doesn't behave like a plugin that processes incoming synth audio. It's all synthesized in a way that *compliments* the synth.

author: LAPhill
content:
To @Deleted User 's question about separating articulations: Yes and no. If you're working with a Hans Zimmer style production, the orchestra will record a separate pass of long notes (everyone on the melody/chords) and a pass of shorts (ostinatos and riffs). So if the parts are really that distinct, especially if they overlap, then it makes sense to deliver them split. 

I have longs and short notes split to different inputs in Cubase so that I can get granular with how much reverb to add (longs usually need a little bit more to help glue the transitions together), but if they're meant to be performed as a single line, then I would deliver it merged. Does that make sense?

author: Deleted User
content:
I find that delays can take some aggresive EQs depending on the style. Give a wild boost on area where I want the delay to cut through and turn the overall delay down - and then compress it a little bit to duck it. 

At least for reverb- I find it’s not always necessarily to have a dry signal keying the compressor to duck the reverb.  Sometimes just a compressor directly on the channel will do something similar and less dramatic than ducking if that’s what is needed for the song, 

Also I find faders very helpful in automating effects. Because I don’t always want them to duck in the same shape or ducking is something I’d do to change the nature of the tail and will still need some additional shaping to give specialness to different moments.

For vocals I like copying the audio track and make separate fx tracks because I only want it on certain words. Even for overall effect, I use a separate track so I can take out certain words from reverb or clip gain them. Or even fade in words when I don’t want the early part of reverb poking out too much in certain parts.

author: Rob Domos
content: Fun fact, that phase delay/group delay differential being a function of time means that it’s bottlenecked by sample rate, so at higher sample rates you’ll have less of this effect and you’ll retain more solidity and texture in the sounds you EQ

author: Rob Domos
content: This is also the biggest reason hardware EQ’s are still preferable. People think it’s the “analog vibe” their into, or whatever, and I’m sure occasionally they are going for those saturation artifacts, but the biggest benefit by far is the fact that in the analog domain, phase delay and group delay differential are not bottlenecked by samplerate, so they can be far more linear

author: jantrit
content:
Drums - dark red 
Bass - blue
Sub bass - dark blue
Piano - blue
Keys like rhodes - light blue
Synths and organ - turquoise 
Guitars  - green
Strings - green for violins/ violas and then blue as you get to cello and basses
Vocals - yellow
Doubles - darker yellow
Bvs - various shades of orange and brown
Rooms and reverbs- purple
Perc, samples and sound effecty stuff - pink
Horns - depends sometimes green sometimes yellow

Auxs are the standard protools colour, master same thing. Print track is tape brown 😆

Always start with drums, overs than kick/ snare then rooms. Bass comes next, then through rest of the rhythm  section to any other instrumentation. Then vocals and finally bvs

Auxiliaries all somewhere in the middle usually after bass or keys/ guitar. Then print track and master.

author: jantrit
content: This was really refreshing to read. I had experienced somewhat a crisis in confidence in my early days with a similar situation. Very young artist, their first record and lots of notes that ended up with us circling endlessly. Sometimes it feels like you’re on top of the ship with a pair of binoculars watching the iceberg get closer lol. Its all part of this thing that we do, gotta take the rough with the smooth. Sometimes you can spot this situation before it occurs and help avoid it. Other times you gotta roll with the punches. Like others have said when you find those situations where everything flows with an artist and there’s a level of trust in the room it’s absolutely incredible, nothing quite like it. There’s a guy here in Philly that try’s to work very quickly he says “there’s no room in my process for people to start doubting or second guessing” I thought that was quite interesting.  Also @NoahNeedleman  didn’t mean to give you the finger lol it was early, emojis are small and I didn’t have my glasses on

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: Deleted User
content:

I know when things get past -14dBFS ish, my kick and low end is gonna start getting buried (maybe it doesn’t have to, but I don’t know how to yet). 

Maybe I should probably leave more headroom, but if I leave more headroom than -1db my mix doesn’t get loud enough. often have to turn down the mix by -1 db or so pre Mixbus because it clips after riding faders. then I compensate my clipper or limiter up by a dB. This may look like arbitrary number fidgeting, but finding my way around the digital room without compromising loudness has been pretty tough

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @KushKadett Things sometime shift when bouncing parts from some DAWs. Matt places a square wave at the end of each track as a sync guide to check. Sample accurate means that the bounced file is identical to source.  Inverting the phase on the bounced file and playing back simultaneously should result in 100% silence (unless some reverbs and time based fx are used which print differently everytime)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A producer buddy of mine asked me yesterday how often I listen in mono while mixing. I said “When I find myself using too many stereo imagers to make things fit, sometimes I’ll check to see what kind of fuckery I’m causing. But honestly who listens in mono anymore?”

He reminded me a lot of small Bluetooth speakers are in mono, so I decided this morning to take a fresh look at a tune I’m producing/mixing, starting in mono. 

The leveling choices totally broke down when I switched to stereo, but I think the mix is much better and it happened faster cause I was forced to look at the eq in relation to the center elements, so even when I spread them back out there was more room for the vocal kik snare bass to speak. 

Y’all ever start a mix in mono? Or work with mono as a tool for extended periods?

author: river
content:
As I like to mix loud, I take inspiration from a method I found called "clip to zero" when it comes to returns/buses/groups (I'll name them buses.)
And also Skrillex and his crazy groups. He showed his screen for a music video a while ago so it's prolly changed but still gave me inspiration.

It'll look something like
Drum bus + drum room bus, grouped together = drum sum bus.
Synth bus  + synth FX bus = synth sum bus
Vocal bus + vocal fx bus = vocal sum.

If it calls for it and I'm feeling spicy, have another group which contains just my bass elements as their own sum group.

Depending on the track, and how important I think any single element is over the other, I might do something like further group/bus together my drums and synths. Leaving me with 2 buses to balance against each other.

author: chrissorem
content: Im curious what  peoples approach is to in person mix notes when someone wants a big picture change on a mix when it’s a foundation change. For example: say the track is build on a particular low end and when you change it the mix no longer feels correct and you find you need to re frame a few things and might need to spend quite a bit of time on it to get it to feel correct again?  Do you work on it with them in the room and re build or do you stop and say I’ll send you another Version later and re group after?  The reason I ask is I generally want to spend more time on ideas than the artist, they may say yes that’s great and let move on and I may want to work on it for a bit in  more detailed manner.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Actually love having artists in the room for the big changes, but I like to include them in the prioritizing department. 

“That one is gonna take a minute to implement and here’s why, you cool to hang while I do that or should we go through the rest of the notes first?”

author: chrissorem
content: Yeah man! I with it. But I find some things  take a me a few hours to figure out and I know for them it’s just one note in the list but for me I need it to lock and feel right. I had this happen a few times and in my head I know I have 10 more songs still to get through and want to utilize the time I have with everyone in the room well.

author: Adam Thein

If it’s exposed like an acoustic/vocal only track then usually I reach for short reverbs, maybe ambience type or nonlinear.

If it’s in a sort of standard form pop/rock thing then I’m looking for other sections of the song that I can duplicate and fly over a separate performance to double.

Other things to try:
ADT
Any flavor of chorus, modulated delay
EQ differences between left and right side

author: BoozleBAM
content: I followed up until: 1 - The masking frequencies part. Are you saying that the reverb can have frequencies that mask the original vocal track? If so, I do think I've observed this phenomenon before. And 2: I don't even freaking know what an effects return is. lol. I'm so remedial with all this.

author: chrissorem
content: No worries.  Yes frequency masking or congestion is like two people talking at once at the same volume. Your Brain interrupts this as blurry and confusing. That’s fine if you want it to sound unison. But if the goal is clarity and separation then you need to find a place where one isn’t in the way of the other. I like to think of this as guiding the ear. Example: I’d like to hear the vocal close but I want to feel longer.  In this instance I’d use pre delay in the reverb and darken the reverb  to achieve this.

author: chrissorem
content: An fx return is simple. Think of this. I have an echo chamber. I’m sending the vocal to a speaker in the echo chamber and I’m recording  the echo in the room with a mic. This would be the return. This concept is the same with an fx unit. You send a signal to the fx and the output of the fx is the return

author: BoozleBAM
content: Sorry, just deleted my message by accident. What I said was: So, we can eq both the sound of the reverb going in and the sound of the reverb going out, correct? If I recal corectly, one of my favorite room emulations/ reverbs has a "preamp" eq section and a "post" eq section": https://www.patreon.com/posts/room041-55993203

author: chrissorem
content: Yes exactly. I have a real plate at my studio and when I’m recording. I usually eq the send to the plate and use pre delay on the send. I print the plate back into the session(this would be the return) and I could always eq the return more or delay it more or less

author: BoozleBAM

content: I have a console so the vocal is being sent via a aux send. The aux can be eq’d and delayed before it physically hits the plate

author: chrissorem
content: The channel has the input, let’s say in this case it’s a vocal. And let’s say you have 2 auxiliary sends on the channel. The main fader is for your monitoring/mix. And the aux send can be anything you want. The physical out of the send me from the console can plug into a plate reverb or a headphone amp. And you can send a variable amount to either

author: Nick Stetina
content: In my experience, adopting the band solo approach takes some reps and intentional listening to refs you love. It’s easy to listen in band solo, and the corrective EQ you have up becomes Thor’s hammer and everything sounds like a nail that need.smash.now. Especially in that ‘Bass’ band…it can be illuminating in some pop stuff, like “oh, they really cleaned up the low end on the sides, there’s this certain V-shape going to the mix in an M/S sense” but I’ve totally neutered what was cool about drum room mics in a mix when trying this approach on a more natural sounding punk/rock tune. So I guess as with anything with great power comes great responsibility, haha

author: Zack Hames
content:
Something that’s helped me, especially with dense rock mixes, is recognizing all the frequency ranges add up;

So, how I use this, is I could do 2-4dB cuts around 1-2k in my guitars and overheads and room mics on drums, then suddenly I have a great little hole for vocals. And those elements all add up to enough 2k in the mix.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Great arrangement, great playing, great recording and then mixed in a full range setup (which @cian riordan’s room is)

author: Nick Stetina
content: I like having Auratones available to flip to for that kind of mid range check. Your room acoustics are always important, but I find they’re also a little more forgiving in that respect. If you have a handful of refs on hands that you like the balance of, I bet an A/B flip between those and what you’re working on  could be insightful. Not to *match* of course, but just getting a sense of general presentation.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Id be happy to listen as well bro! Hard to say what will be right without hearing it.

-EQ and levels are a given...so apart from that...
-Light ratio compression on busses + master (light ratio like 1.25-2:1 allows you to keep things in compression and still feel natural)
-Purposeful reverb/delay to make a believable space 
-Don't be afraid to try a short verb on the 2bus
-Stages of saturation

The biggest thing for sparse/soft arrangements is making the space it lives in believable (if it supposed to feel natural)

content:
phase shift with high pass filters are pretty common but rarely sounds too intense unless the center freq is in the middle of of a lot of info, I'm sure someone more technically savvy can run point on this better. 

but no2 is pretty simple. we both hear and feel music. those delays often add a feeling of depth or can also be used to enhance /adjust grooves in a way that's not invasive, Ina way that make a difference to the feeling of the music but may not be obvious when only focusing on how it sounds

author: shaunobi
content: I used to think of LCR as not having as many “options”. But in talking to a friend, he really opened up my eyes on this. Try thinking in “triangles” and “planes”. So, take a mono synth and put it center, but then take the reverb and put it right. Or take a guitar room mic and put it right for close mic, but grab the stereo room mics and pan them R and C. Or two close mics on two cabs and pan them L and C. Here’s a graphic he sent me that helped it click:

content: It was a full take. No comping but when the singer sings out he would excite the room and has a dominant 1-3k range, yet he wants the vocal to sound close and warm. I started the mix with only the vocal and was happy with the way it was sounding  gbut as I add the other instruments in the vocal felt a bit distant in the 1-3k range. I realized that if I ducked those frequencies in the other instruments mics a bit when he’s singing it felt close and warm.

author: spectrummasters
content:
fwiw, im in a good position to experiment currently as i get quick money on site and then have the time where i dont have the recall/revisions/deadlines workflow demands that most talented / industry people here do, so i  have taken the last year out to spend a lot of time thinking, learning and planning how to offer something fresh as a mixer here in Lonoon and i dont want to sound like anyone else. So ,im ditching gullfosses and soothes and spectral shapers and MB's..and im breaking my buses out to h/w mixers and boxes so that i can hopefully induce some electromagnetic phenomena or some "accidental" errors , like  my two year old coming in and turning knobs on the gear without me seeing (as he does) and then i mix through it , unknowingly....and ive introduced something wrong, something a perfect alogirthm could never give me ....something........difffffferent. Im v. bored atm with listening to perfect productions and mixes. Imho they are delicious and tasty and  malnourishing like McDonalds.

Imho, the sound of  Robert Johnson recorded, singing crossroads in a shack somewhere a 100 years ago will still outlast the bombastic incredibly perfect production/mixes i feel encouraged to mimic today. i feel like perfection has been overdone at this point. Lets f things up

it might be a naff idea but , where im at....since doing band stuff....that tom elmhirst quote about there being no perfect mix....and the mix is the mix that happened at the moment where eevryone in the room agreed was it......and not to be touched again...this is what im fascinated with at the mo....and doing the print with me and the drummer on my current mixes pushing the analogue faders (with the busses stemmed out of the daw) together. Making it performative and transient

Try duplicating the track, hard planning, and putting a mono delay on one of them. Start 15ms with no feedback, mix at 100%.

author: toohighprod
content: Quick question for my recording and mixing engineers. If you track or receive a recording with multiple room mics how are you addressing phase? As a mixing engineer when you get the drum stems are you moving your tracks to line up the phase? If so are you using the snare as your reference point to line everything up?

author: samvalentine
content: I think it's important to keep the room mics in phase with one another but if they're far enough from the drums the signal is naturally delayed enough that I can't imagine it will interact poorly with your close mics / OH... maybe flip the phase on the room mic bus or whatever to see if something sounds better but I doubt it would be a drastic change

author: toohighprod
content: I run into them often when receiving stems with multiple room mics. It usually can be handled by just flipping polarity. author: PKirk
content:
According to ChatGPT: 

Velvet noise decorrelation is a technique used in audio processing to create a sense of spatiality or wideness in a sound. It involves using a sequence of sparse, randomly placed pulses (velvet noise) to introduce small delays to the audio signal. This process helps to break the coherence of the original signal, reducing correlation between channels and enhancing the perception of space and depth in the audio.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Actually, delays are super easy. You just input a quick blast of white noise (your impulse) through the delay device and record the output. That output becomes your IR which you can then use in any convolver plugin to apply echo to your sounds.

Of course it's not that useful because you can't tweak the echo parameters. You'd have to capture an IR for every setting that you want.

author: Tristan
content:
Good problem to have. The first thing that jumped out to me was the fact you mix and master. I personally struggle the most with different types of workloads than one of the same. You might be more capable in that area. I assume you want to keep doing it all, but I just turn down work that isn’t my ultimate goal if it’s causing me workload stress. My feeling is mastering requires more organization than mixing, too. 

What’s your fee structure like? Without making too many assumptions you might need to lob on or lob on more aggressive rush fees and also manage expectations on projects that dip below your rate. I mention to any client that I don’t charge full rate that full rate projects that I either have on the board or come in take priority so there might be some delay in delivery of both first passes and or revisions. I also quietly prioritize clients who give me the most work and have done so for years.
 
How fast are you at mixing? I can do a mix in as little as an hour if I need to, not ideal, but it happens if the request is urgent enough. I also have 2 identical rigs and can make revisions at home rather than sit around at the studio waiting for notes.

How involved and capable is your assistant?

It would also make sense for the sound/concept of the album to emerge as you progress through your mixes. It might click right away with the first track, or it might not fully take shape until you're working on the third song for ex. I think it's totally fine and part of the process. author: Sam Segarra
content: Hi guys - anxiety-driven question here: when using 2 reverbs on vocals(in this case an "all vocal" bus) would you worry about matching predelay times? Does anyone have an opinion on that, beyond "whatever sounds good"? I have a chamber with no predelay and a plate with 101 ms currently.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't see it being a big problem, if one of the verbs is mixed relatively low. If they're both super wet, it will probably feel very obviously "off" *if* one of the pre-delay times are a bad fit.

If the verbs are in series (as opposed to parallel) then I could see pre-delay time being a bigger deal because the PD on the first verb would delay the PD of the second.

I could also see pre-delay time being a factor if the vocal is very staccato. That should be obvious, though.

Otherwise, it's good 'ol "use your ears" and I wouldn't give it too much thought as long as you're getting the effect that you want. If you're not sure, try matching PD times and see how it feels (better/worse?) then move on.

Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I have a limited understanding but by playing and recording an impulse (see clapping, Ballon pop, sine wave sweep) into a room you measure the response and behaviour of all frequencies in that space(aka the attack, decay etc). 

Then by playing a dry signal through the IR, it recreates a reverb/convulsion of how that sound would behave in the measured space. 

With acoustic instruments just imagine the body of the instrument is like a miniature room that you're measuring. Play a DI track through the IR and the goal is to replicate the acoustic space of the instrument on the dry signal

author: Val ᶠʳ

Basically, yes. I like too see IRs as an audio "mold" of a space. 🙂
Years ago, IRs reverb was often considered more "realistic" than algorithmic ones, because of the amount of details they reproduce, but I'm not sure it's still the case, compared to recent VSTs.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Depth in a mix is fairly simple, if you can hear it. You have a few basic tools and a few more complex ones, but overall it looks like this. 

Brighter+louder=closer
Darker+quieter=further

This is also true for bottom end *mostly.*

Panning also pushes things out of the center and allows you to play with a lot more area in which to push things back. 

If you don’t have the luxury of panning, as with a snare drum, then you have volume & eq as your main tools. 

Then you have reverb. Shorter predelay, fewer short reflections & louder tails. Choosing a larger algo like a hall, etc.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're in pro-tools, sidechains are a constantly moving target with delay compensation, so I would always opt to just automate the gate threshold. Little more work but then its nice to be able to control the range afterwards and allow some bleed back in to help gel the drum sound.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content: I make key spikes and run them into sidechain inputs. For a while PT had a smaller limit on delay compensation on sidechains but they increased it a few years ago. I still make dummy outputs for the key tracks which seems to keep the delay compensation updated and happy, never have issues these days. I love being able to use the spikes to put my gates anywhere in the chain, or to key compressors/expanders/gates on reverbs or room mics etc. and my ocd is happier with consistent gating each time, as much as I dig the trigger and sonnox gates, I never 100% trust real time ones.

author: Sei046
content:
I mixed two tracks today that are potentially my best mixes ever, low end is perfect (for me) and the mids are crystal, real 3d, can hear the verbs sitting perfectly, no brittleness in the top end. This was after really struggling the last two weeks. How you ask? I used my 100 euro pair of jbl Bluetooth headphones with horrible mids and super exaggerated lows and highs. For whatever reason the volume balance I was doing on them before a single bit of processing was better than any mix I had done lately. 

So… relook at my room acoustics? The thing is though they sounded great when I threw them up on the system, as I wanted, no big surprises, just sounded way better than on the headphones. 

I found the really exaggerated lows made setting the kick and bass much easier, and the sizzly  top meant I was really sensitive to it and was drawn to address sounds that were a bit harsh. 

It’a a bit like the inverse of working on NS10s. Whatever works I suppose!

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This doesn’t answer your question, but maybe it’ll help prevent this issue in the future:

I don’t think focusing on one element for a long time is ultimately helpful for the process. 

Vocals need a LOT of processing usually, so I find doing one element of that at a time, rather than all of them in one fell swoop, to be helpful. 

I like to start with an autotune, basic eq & comp & some simple ambience to out the vocal inside the song. 

Fix what’s really sticking out and then move on to other elements. 

Go back and get the esses & breaths in order 

Move back to other shit 

Come back and melodyne for real, focus on the areas that have been bugging but also tightening up timing as much as possible. 

The back to other shit. Then back for delay & ambience throws (usually toward the end of the process)

author: Rob Domos
content:
@Nomograph Mastering 

There’s so many layers to this conversation. 

One layer is: *are methods of reframing what you’re hearing inherently a crutch for poor monitoring?*

The 400hz high pass that you monitor through part time on every master would imply not. 

As someone with pretty good monitoring (80% of a Gerhard room and MUM 8s), I personally still find these kind of things very useful within a mixing context. 

I think you’re imagining a whackamole scenario of revolving bandpasses throughout the process and repeatedly throwing off the brain’s fr curve, when in reality it’s a once per mix check at the 85% mark that takes about 5 minutes total to see if anything that’s been overlooked jumps out when adjacent information isn’t distracting from it.

The way this helps me hone in on relationships between elements that I’ve been neglecting is pretty significant. I lean heavily “vocal > everything” when I mix, and nearly every time I do this bandpassing reframe I notice something I’d missed in the interplay between the rest of the elements and the whole project is upgraded as a result. 

I think it’s totally fair to warn against the pitfalls of such maneuvers in the same way that it’s fair to warn against abusing energy drinks, but when it’s just once a week before an intense workout, an energy drink is actually a big win with little to no downside.

I've had clients where I produced the shit out of backvocals. author: Chris Lyon
content:
From my experience, if you focus it on low mids rather than harsh unpleasant frequencies while sidechaining, it can make room for the body of vocals or important instruments to cut through.

A lot of the time, those resonances are the defining characteristics of each sound so side chaining even to harsh high-mid info can allow the character of a focus track to cut while limiting the stacking of those possibly harsh frequencies with other tracks. 

Experiment with the sidechain in mid/side unlinked and you can get more aggressive with sidechaining the lead vocal to the instrumental. In a dense pop mix, it can be a lifesaver.

author: cian riordan
content: I find it useful to just have a grasp on where each section of the song is sitting LUFS-wise. If the first verse is blazing at -6 LUFS, then you're not gonna have much room to go up if you're looking for a lift in the chorus. If the intro of the song is coming in at -22 LUFS, then its probably gonna sound extremely quiet relative to another song's final chorus (or even worse, another song on some streaming playlist).
